To be honest, I liked the anime a little bit, the plot is good, atleast. It's one of those animes where it's not THAT good but you like it for some reason and can't stop watching. I think this is my first review so bare with me.
Characters: (6/10) I don't think a lot of the characters have much of a personality..I think Kuroneko has the most personality out of everyone. Kotori has some personality, Kazumi just spits out perverted stuff a lot, then gets tsundere..She's pretty unique but that's not as much as a personality that anime characters should have. Like one moment she talksabout sex and all that stuff, and keeps making moves on Murakami, then gets all shy and backs up.  Murakami doesn't have much of one, and I think Kana should of talked and done more in the anime. Kuroneko has a lot of character though, and I haven't seen on like her.


Sound: (7/10) I'm more used to most animes where there's song lyrics and everything for the opening, instead of just instrumental. The music didnt match the anime at all. It should of maybe had a sad, or calming tune? The voice actors were pretty good, although Kazumi's voice actors could be a little bit better. They match the characters though. Like how Kuroneko's voice is calm and mature, it fits her kind and quiet personality. Kazumi is a tsundere, so her voice was pretty much good, it just doesn't sound feminine enough for her cute tsundere moments.  Kotori's voice actor was pretty good, the high pitched-uneasy voice fits her moe personality well. The other voice actors are okay.


Art: (5/10) I think the art was okay, but it didnt match the anime well. I think maybe the artist of Another or The Irregular of Magic High School's art would of fit the anime more. Also, the characters look pretty weird when they cry, and if you look closely and avoid the hair, Kazumi's face looks like a guy.


Story: (9/10) The plot was really good, with Murakami's backstory with Kuroneko connecting everything to the witches. But there are extra details like at the beginning when Kuroneko used Kana's power to see future visions to save people. She did that on the first episode, but she stopped doing it. I think they rushed it a bit and totally forgot that. Also, the also episode disappointed me a lot. The battle between Valkyria and Kuroneko was too boring, with not enough action. They should of shown a better fight, with more powers used. I thought Kuroneko's power would be more brilliant, with tons of comeback moves. But there was barely any combat in the battle. And also, it didnt say much about stars in the anime. I thought it would. And I didn't see a point in Nanami. I know she helped him, but she should of appeared more. And Murakami cares too much about one person when he's only known them for a day or less. So side characters should show up more. And at the point where the characters think they're gonna die in a week, they should of been more sad about it instead of joking around. 


Enjoyment: (7/10) I did like the anime, for some reason. Maybe because of the plot, or maybe because I just like the fact that the anime and to do with death, since I'm a horror fan. I liked Kuroneko and Murakami's unique past. Most anime, characters pasts are like "my parents died in a fire" or something, so I like his unique past. It was pretty good, I guess.



Overall: (7/10) I really wanted to see Kuroneko's powers, so I kept watching, although I got disappointed in the end. The first few episodes got me interested. They introduced Kuroneko well, and had a good explanation of the plot and everything in the first episode. The anime was pretty rushed, and had some pretty bad details to it, but it has it's good points. Most of it is pretty average.

Alright so Gokukoku no Brynhildr (Brynhildr in the Darkness)
The music was just really weird. We'll start with that. The first OP is dubstep for some reason and it really doesn't fit the mood of the show at all which is supposed to be kind of dark mixed with some happy scenes. Then the first OP stays throughout the show until the last like 4 episodes and it turns to metal which still doesn't fit the show. The ending theme was a nice little thing that absolutely did not fit the show. The OP and ED vids were appropriate though. The first OP showed bloodon the young girls' bodies which was a sure indicator that there was more to come. 


The themes of the show were very weird. I started it thinking that it was a normal show and there'd be blood but not many deaths. Actually more people die than I thought and some people that you don't want to die, do. The lack of deus ex machina actually does this show justice because it doesn't turn the show completely into a teenage witch killer show. Lots of ecchi in the show for no reason. I think they were trying to create an uneasy atmosphere by juxtaposing really sad and dark moments right next to happy scenes with nudity. 


LOTS of ideas were taken from Elfen Lied. You could say that this show was heavily influenced and probably created after someone read the manga or saw the show. Actually this is crappier Elfen Lied. For kids.

Bodies split in half, blood, theatrical breakdowns where the main character screams as if in agony and appears to lose his mind every time someone dies. And let's not forget that these witches are all girls who were experimented on from a young age. Add changes of heart in least expected characters, scientists, the main bad guy trying to reincarnate someone from long ago- blah blah blah Elfen Lied (closer to manga actually now that I think of it.)


The characters are actually pretty likeable. No character development whatsoever except on the male lead and on the female lead though. One of the witches is paralyzed except for her left hand which types out words for her which is funny because during sad scenes it goes to everyone's face for their reaction and hers is always the same and luckily they added in the typing sounds consistently. The male lead is very smart but he's not OP in fact he gets his ass kicked and cries all the time.


6/10



TL;DR: If you liked Elfen Lied, you'll like this. Just not nearly as much.

Brynhildr in Darkness was something I was anticipating after watching the second OP a few times. I feel as a 13 Episode anime it was portrayed pretty well but there was a few things that really didn'ts it well with me in the end.
Story 6/10
I feel the story was accomplished but not really executed in a very good way. The first episodes had very good flow and was really interesting. Around episode 10 is where they start cramming in way too many things. It wasn't really healthy at all to be quite honest. Also the ending was very rushed and didn't feel very complete atall, it feels almost like a cliff hanger. As in regard to the actually events however, it was entertaining but felt too much like Deadman Wonderland with the whole "pills to survival" thing and they crammed the aliens in as a more "WTF" sort of feel which wasn't great at all.


Art 9/10

I actually enjoyed the art style quite a bit. It was very pretty but one thing though was why did they have to lens flare every sight of nudity. It was very annoying and I wish they never would have done that. Also they did do some minor CGI effects that wasn't very good either.  The prime example being the bus in some episodes. Didn't really fit the animation style at all.


Sound 9/10

OST was actually very impressive and was the main reason I wanted to watch this anime. Only downside was the second OP was not used enough. You only get to hear it for 4 episodes and thats it. Kind of shitty if you ask me but whatever.


Character 7/10

I liked the  characters in this anime but being so short there was really no time to develop any of the load of characters they introduce every episode. It would have been better to get more back story for more of the characters but just with the time it didn't happen.


Overall 7/10

This was no way a bad anime. A lot of people said the ending was bad and yes they were all right. But It is still worth the watch. It was very interesting but this had so much potential to be an amazing anime but sadly, it wasn't compromised on. If your gnna watch it just don't take the ending as an overall view of how the anime was entirely.

Sound - now this was something i loved of the anime, the op's were awesome, fit the series nice, and ed was nice and relaxing and liked it, ost was pretty cool throughout the anime. this is probably the only reason i kept watching this anime


Animation - was alright.


Overall - dont waste your time with this show, youll think its getting better and the story is moving on but it never does, its just one more girl to the harem, and murakami saying he'll protect the girls every 5 minutes, only watch the op's and ed if you really want to. honestly they could of done a much better job with this anime, but i just couldnt take it seriously, sorry if i bashed on this anime too much.

Gokukoku no Brynhildr or Brynhildr in the darkness is a good example of an anime which had potential but failed to deliver in the end. A show which could have been exceptionally good but turned out to be just another average release of the season.
Story: 6
The only reason I'm giving the story a 6 is because of its concept and the atmosphere which the show achieved in the first half of the series. The show was rushed and horribly paced mainly through the second half of the series. The dark atmosphere which the created wished for was virtually non-existent in the show except for certain,very small points in the show. The show mainly failed due to it being rushed and not much time was given for character development and allowing the viewers to get interested in the story and characters but this was expected considering the manga had over 100 chapters and the entire anime was only 13 episodes but this could be different in the case that there may be more to come as I haven't read the manga yet.


Art: 7


The art of Gokukoku no Brynhildr was average and didn't really have any exceptional moments but it did suit the anime and not much can be complained about. More work could have been put into the fight scenes between the witches. The most extravagant part of the artwork was the scenery which I felt was much better than what we usually get in most anime.


Sound: 8


Sound is the strongest point about this series and really did a good job in setting the right mood. The first OP was really good with its mix of instrumental and dubstep and was really different compared to what we usually hear in anime. The second OP I felt fit the anime but I personally did not like it much and felt that there was no need for a change of OP for a 13 episode series.  


Characters: 6


The character development in the show was non-existent as I mentioned earlier and was one of the key reasons for this show getting such negative feedback. Our protagonist Murukami at first felt like a good MC with him being super smart, kind and willing to do anything to protect those he cares about but eventually after his insistent whining and confusion throughout the show with him needing help from every female in sight, he began to get quite annoying. The main female characters were also not very great with the exception of Kazumi who was the only character which I felt had a little spunk and an interesting attitude. Some of the support characters like Nanami had more character development than the mains and were much better also. Overall if they put more effort into character development, the characters may have been more pleasing and the show would have been much better.


Enjoyment: 7


When I first started this show it was quite enjoyable with its story and gory scenes which were unexpected but after a while it wasn't as enjoyable as it should have been but more into that would be spoiler territory.


Overall: 6


This anime is for those who like good plots but you would have to be willing to look over most of its flaws. I would say this is a watch but not of much priority. Go read the manga instead.

*May include some spoilers
Gokukoku no Brynhildr is just another anime that had the potential to be great but turned out to be mediocre.
Theres only one thing that has made me continue watching this, and thats the story. There are what could be called unnecessary, filler-ish episodes (though not many), and endless/pointless characters being introduced, but the actual idea of the story stands out.
What pulled me in at first was the idea of Kuroha being Kuroneko. I kept asking myself, 'how could that be?' 'when will we find out if Kuroha is Kuroneko?' 'if Kuroha is Kuroneko, how did that happen? I thought Kuroneko was dead!'
We'renow 12/13 episodes in, and I'm still wondering about the Kuroha/Kuroneko story, especially since we're introduced to Valkryia, who looks uncannily like Kuroha and somehow knows her from the past.\n
We're also told that Kuroha hasn't unleashed her full power - something I'm looking forward to seeing. All in all, the plot keeps you wondering, and it's what has kept me watching this show. I don't know how they're going to tie it all up in one episode, though. Guess we'll have to wait and see.\n\n
Now, the weak part of Gokukoku no Brynhildr is none other than its characters. \n
To me, characters make up a very important part in an anime, and it's hard to watch something that doesn't have at least a couple of decent characters.\n
That's what has bothered me in Gokukoku no Brynhildr. Although they try to build up the characters with short backstories, everyone still seems so one dimensional. The only people with real personalities would be some of the supporting characters, and Kazumi and Kana. Even though they do have 'personalities', they aren't very good ones. Kazumi oversexualizes everything and wants to lose her virginity. Its played off that shes a 'tryhard' whos cute when you get to know her, but in reality she just seems so annoying.\n
Kana, on the other hand, would be fun to watch if she wasn't plastered to her seat all day (although I understand WHY they did that, it's just kind of annoying that one of the interesting characters can't even move.)\n
Apart from their personalities, the other thing that bothers me is the half-assed melodrama. "Why would you give up your life to save me?" says Murakami, with a straight face. Two seconds later, he decides to have a normal conversation with one of his girls. There shouldn't be so much death if they can't even play off a proper, shocked reaction from the characters.\n
All in all, the characters are Gokukoku no Brynhildrs weak point. If they were done well, the anime would be close to perfect.\n\n
The sound and art are both decent. I liked the first opening song a lot, but other than that not much stood out.\n
The art is alright. The character designs are done well, and all in all the scenes give of a 'feel', but the art is very generic - not anything you cant see in other anime.\n\n
Story: 9\n
Art: 7\n
Sound: 7\n
Characters: 4\n
Enjoyment: 8\n
Overall: 7.

Just finished re-watching this series and just thought, "Man, what's wrong with the anime? That was a pretty good watch yet the ratings looks like the total opposite." Yes it was rushed, but this is an adaptation, and the source material is entirely a different story. 
The story is generic yet unique, it is something refreshing and has a strong potential to become an amazing sci-fi. Themes such as romance, childhood tragedies, mystery, suspense, fanservice, and harem are all in one package. It's not a very good idea though, because the execution is quite flawed because of lack of focus in one aspect of itsthemes. It doesn't know where it stands at times, because of distractions such as drama scenes then unnecessary ecchi fanservice scenes then it turns out to be a comedy then a cheesy romance that has dark tones surrounded by glitters. The strong point though is the amount of fresh mysteries and thrilling suspense, which can guarantee your satisfaction with the story.


Now I can't deny the fact that the art is pretty good, we've got a lot of of sights here. Background sceneries are very pleasing to the eyes, character designs are simple yet what makes them pretty is the use of colors, high quality animation is always present most of the time. Their eyes are very detailed, I haven't seen any anime that has these unique beautiful eyes. See for the cover. It has a dark atmosphere with slight dark tones in it. It can set the mood of the show with different scenes, whether it's bright or dark, the art is good quality work. Animation is always solid and crisp, but it's just  nearly as perfect.


For the sound, I really loved both the openings, they really fit for the anime's themes perfectly, but I'll just say that the second opening was unnecessary. It could have stayed at the original opening, but the second one is not bad either. The ending is catchy and fits the sad and soft side of the show, plus it's nice to hear the whole girl cast singing. Soundtracks are just so good, it plays a role to the scene which can either give you tension, feels, easiness or goosebumps. The voice acting were decent and I think it's still above average. 


Characters are very interesting and played their respective roles all throughout the series well. I can't deny the fact that Ryouta is another generic harem lead character. But his role doesn't just stop there. He has unique traits that make him a well generic character, with good character developments and good backstory execution, his character was written very well. Obviously for a harem, we have a main girl. Kuroha is quite dense and an airhead, but her personality blends well with her chemistry with Ryouta. The other girls are decently written as well, they each have individual screentime to showcase themselves. The only problem is probably the ones that show up in the later half though, as they didn't get developments or screentime which means they can't get any sympathy or you won't care when they get hurt or die. I won't mention those characters so see for yourself. They're just like plot devices but when you see it outside the box they all have roles to achieve success in the show. 


I think I really enjoyed the anime so much that I put it on my favorites despite it's flaws and flops. But don't get the wrong idea here, my favorites are a different story, and it's mostly based on enjoyment and not biased. This is entirely different from Elfen Lied. The amount of suspense in a single scene can make you go crazy during cliffhangers, and crave for more. Lastly I would say that the anime is VERY different from the manga on how it is adapted, but let's think that this is anime and it shouldn't be compared with its source material by any means. Gokukoku no Brynhildr has above average production values, and overall I think it was a very unique sci-fi with drama and romance undertones. It is unpredictable, and knows how to handle mystery elements well and present it gracefully to the viewers. 


Note : I ANALYZED THOROUGHLY BY RE-WATCHING THE ANIME AND CAN'T FIND MAJOR PLOT HOLES. IT IS NOT A BUTCHERED ANIME, BUT THE ADAPTATION DIDN'T GO WELL. IT IS NOT A BAD ANIME.


Story - 8 (Interesting premise and a promising plot)

Art - 9 (Solid and detailed. Can't see any flaws and just near as perfection.)

Sound - 8 (Appreciable, good, and moving. Not bad but not the best either.)

Character - 8 (Well written and developed except for a few supporting characters.)

Enjoyment - 10 (VERY enjoyable from start to finish. Can make you stay at the edge of your seats.)

Overall - 9 (Excellent watch. High production values.)

This anime series was created by Lynn Okamoto, the creator of Elfen Lied one of my favorite animes ever so I was pumped to watch this. It revolves around high school boy Ryouta Murakami, who cannot forget his female childhood friend whom he let die in an accident. Feeling that he must fulfill their promise of proving the existence of aliens, he has continuously looked up at the starry sky as a member of the astronomy club. One day, a girl named Neko Kuroha who looks exactly like his childhood friend appears as a transfer student who also turns out to be a witch. Okaythis series, I enjoyed it as a whole. The plot is fairly simple, which for you could be a good thing but for me it held this show down. Things just happen here, it tries to convey emotional weight to scenes and they just fall flat which falls mostly on the characters. I didnt like many characters in this anime. The main character Murakami, is a typical main character that does everything as he should and completely throws his life in disarray for these girls he barely knows. Neko, the second lead in this anime is one of the most bland characters I've ever seen in an anime. Nothing she says or does for the most part is interesting and honestly if she was a more compelling character I may have enjoyed this anime more. Most of the characters were average and didn't have much to them and when they died I didn't affect me much. On the other hand, Kazumi was great, I grew to love her brass attitude and perverted ways and to me she was the highlight of this anime. Art and sound were good but nothing special to me. The villains were weak and had uninteresting motives as is because they weren't given much depth in the story. The best thing in this anime was a scene with time travel that I wont spoil but it was really well executed and had me in a frenzy watching it. But the weight and purpose of that scene was undermined later in the anime with something anticlimactic that I guess they had to rush because of the short 13 episode run time. Also the twist ish plot development near the end of the anime felt like a let down and characters just appear out of nowhere and  have no real purpose except for plot exposition and to get the important characters from point A to point B. Overall a decent series that had highs that were fun to watch but mostly just slightly above average and not much compared to Okamoto's previous masterpiece Elfen Lied.

SHORT REVIEW
This is a story about cute girls/witches who run away and end up with the main male character, obviously this forms a harem. 
GnB (stands for Gokukoku no Brynhildr not Goliath National Bank) 
GnB isn't afraid to chuck deaths here and there which makes it more darker
Story - It's about runaway witches who are definitely cute, finding a place to stay and they end up with the same male. An evil organization is after them so the male character steps up to help. 
What is really refreshing about this anime is the male lead. In your typical harem the guy has no likable qualities,has the luck of the gods and is in no danger whatsoever. \n
In GnB however, the male lead wants to help and fight for these witches. He is not a wimp who complains a lot and is actually very useful in certain situations. \n\n
Now this is a huge con:\n
If you have read the Manga and loved to see the VA follow it then you're so gonna be disappointed. \n
The anime is 13 episodes long so you can't expect it to complete the manga. However, in the first 10 episodes, 30 chapters were completed which is reasonable. BUT in the last 3 episodes it covered over 60 chapters. Just like that. \n
The ending is rushed as heeeeeeeellll. \n
The only way to actually enjoy this is to see what you get. Don't think about anything else. \n\n

The past cannot be changed or forgotten. That's why to hold on the past always creates suffering, although once it was really wonderful.
Brynhildr in the Darkness is an anime based on a manga by Lynn Okamoto known for his infamous work - Elfen Lied. First impression on Elfen Lied? The one that full with bloody and messy gore scene that even go as far to introduce pedophilia, cruelty, sexuality and nudity. To be honest, it was quite shocking when this anime came out. I nearly think it's as a new version of Elfen lied when it comes to the gore scene. Still, there are quitegore scenes you can't evade. You can't escape from gore if you're going to watch this anime series. Better think carefully. Nevertheless this anime is definitely not a new Elfen Lied version or something like that. Don't compare them! It's wrong! Both anime have its owns greatness. But this anime is so full with new comedy, new concept of story and a good character development involving past and present. 


Side note, I already watch and complete this anime when all of the episodes are already out. Regretfully, I just think to write a review about it just now. Yet, I'm still can feel the enthusiasm about this anime. Let's get back to the story shall we?


Story 

Romance. I'll tell it's directly that this anime have a really good romance inside. Watch this if you a romance genre fans. You will love it! Back to the story. The story of anime itself is pretty amazing. It's slowly build up and the effort has been paid up after the ending of the series. I think it's the fresh one after so many cliché anime I've watched. The theme of memory loss and choosing dark tones is the one of the fact that brings out this anime potential far better. The story tells us about Ryouta, a boy who remembers the promise he had with his childhood friend’s Kuroneko. Nightmare happened when Kuroneko died while saving Ryouta. Full of regrets after the incident that occurs. Ryouta chooses not to forget it and keeps the promise. Yes, to find the real alien. Ryouta keeps up his promise up until his life as a high school student. But, one day, fates change everything when he meets a new transfer student name Kuroha Neko. The past will unfold with the destiny Ryouta never expect. Better take a seat mate. You will love this story. A really good performances by all the character. A big applause please.


Art 

You will like it. The art of this series play an important role to show you. It has been shown a great one as darker feeling in it. Animation inside will startled you. Why not see this for yourself? You can ensure it better this way.


Sound

Honestly, I love the Ops. It's so great while those songs bring this uneasy feeling with darker theme yet fantastic. On the opposite, the ending is quite catchy and might catch your attention before you even realize it. But the ops, I can say it's really fabulous. How fabulous? It’s like Bitch please, I'm fabulous. That one is a quote.


Character 

I also love the character. Kuroneko is so cute! The expressions she makes is simple marvelous. I will keeps saying it's marvelous and marvelous until you get bored of it. The others girl also cute but I think I pick kuroneko! Ehehe. Just thinking it back made me sound a creepy laugh and grin to ear. If I show this face at public. No doubt I will get arrested by police in no time. 


Enjoyment and Overall

Sadly, I want to give this anime a masterpiece but I can't. Since in the last episode I feel like it was way too rushed. You know the feeling when you still eating food at cafeteria but the ring of your school's bell is already ringing. Yea, bullshit man. Other than that, this anime is really a fine piece. While I do feel the shame for comparing both the Elfen Lied (EL) and Gokukoku no brynhildr (GnB) series at first, I had absolutely no idea how excellent it is these two series excel with their different aspects.  In conclusion, everyone can find at least one series that they truly can enjoy as it’s worth a season's worth of anime. As for me, clearly this is the one. Gokukoku series also has its own flaws but the demerit doesn’t stop this show from being a personal favorite of mine.

*WARNING MAY CONTAIN SOME SPOILERS AND I AM NOT LIABLE OF ANY ACCUSATIONS, VIEWER DISCRETION IS ADVISED"
I started watching Gokukoku no Brynhildr anticipating it will be a mystery-drenched anime dealing with aliens and riddles. After reading one of the anime's story summaries, I realized it's rated R17+, implying there has to be some sort of violence and action-based scenes. My curiosity piqued at that moment and I decided to watch the whole of GnB starting from episode 1. Initially, the pilot episode sent chills down my spine, and established a nice, perplexing atmosphere .To me, these first few episodes were a breath of fresh airfor these sci-fi fantasy genres. After the 4th or 5th episode however, things started to spiral downwards, especially because of the sheer amount of fanservice and *tits* the anime suddenly bashes the viewers with. I honestly don't get the point of bringing up a dark and foreboding plotline if the next thing that comes out is 2 girls 1 cup. On the bright side, the raw story of GnB is worth watching, if you’re into the sci-fi mystery and genre. 


Many people would compare GnB with Elfen Lied simply because GnB and Elfen Lied are made by the same creators, and obviously because of this they will have similarities. In my opinion, GnB's storyline/plot derives from Elfen Lied, except this time they removed a lot of gore and it isn't as frightening to see as a whole. Furthermore, they added an unneeded amount of romance which essentially transformed this anime into a light harem, and consequently applied a fatal blow to this particular anime, at least in my opinion.  


I've also read a few parts of the manga version of Gokoku no Brynhilder, and initially this anime had a LOT of potential to be as successful as some of the biggest animes out there such as Shingeki no Kyojin. However and most unfortunately, the anime produced is NOTHING compared to the manga version. The content last episode for example, included literally a THIRD of what's supposed to be in the manga. Sure, anime's aren't supposed to have everything - things get missed out. BUT, some important nitty-gritty has been missed out, and the main arc is given like literally 2 episodes, which resulted in plot holes, ESPECIALLY in the last episode. For example, during that episode, the fight between Kuroha and her evil older sibling, Mako, lasted literally 30 seconds. Furthermore, the final scene with Kotori and Ryouta is cut short, and most of it is just Ryouta weeping and crying.To summarize, so much is left untold, and it seems as if the creators just flippantly squeezed the whole of the manga in 13 frickin episodes leaving the whole story muddied up and ruined. 


I have no complaints to make amount this anime’s sound. Even though the soundtrack doesn’t stand out completely compared to other animes, it has definitely set the mood and the type of story quite well and the OP of GnB is amazing.


The art involved in this anime was okay. The art style is relatively bland, and it doesn't really give any appeal - in a way it makes the anime seem rather old. Basically regarding the art, the anime doesn't live up to the standards of a lot of modern animes but hey it gets the job done. 


In terms of characterization, the anime did decently well. Ultimately Ryouta (the main character) is portrayed as a mildly introverted, perceptive and soft hearted person. Occasionally his personally tips off a bit and becomes too arrogant and reckless which heavily contrasts his thought-to-be collected, logical and docile self. I mean, he's putting his LIFE on line for a few girls that might just die in a few weeks. Furthermore at most times there are situations that are WAY too serious for Routa to doze off and become a major boob critique. Moving on, Kuroneko acts as a distant, poker-faced protagonist who fights alongside with the other witches and Ryouta. I thought that they handled Kuroneko pretty well - they made it clear how she isn't accustomed at all to realistic "human" feelings, and her whole journey consists of unlocking different emotions that are completely new to her. It really sucks how in the last episode, she loses all her memories AGAIN, and the my sense of achievement while watching that part evaporated in thin air. I wouldn't exactly classify Kuroneko as a tsundere, because she wasn't exactly hostile to begin with, save for a few brutal scenes. I feel Kazumi is the main problem of this anime - she's a thirsty, young tsundere girl who is filled with sexual innuendos and craves nothing but Routa's virginity. She serves a purpose of disrupting Ryouta and Kuroneko's lovey dovey relationship, but hey it made the initial bland romance more interesting. Kotori is an overly shy girl with serious stuttering problems and MASSIVE tits. I honestly don't have any problems with her other than the fact that the artists emphasized the hell out of her tits and her personality is so frickin dull and annoying. As the show begins to explore her however, things start getting interesting and it seems she served a purpose at the very end. The antagonists of this show seems to stand out and sink in at the same time. The main one, mr. Chisato is particularly interesting. At first he is portrayed as a ruthless, emotionless "evil scientist" type person, stopping at nothing to capture all of the stray witches. His personality itself emanates an evil aura, making him a typical evil mastermind very similar to Kaiyaba Aihiko from SAO. The most peculiar moment is during one of the final scenes of the last episode, when he very abruptly saves Valkyrie's life, which evokes a powerful message of what it means to be human - you simply cannot take away the "human" part of all of us, regardless of how evil you may be. Although many may have viewed this moment very negatively, and I may sound very subjective but I thought that it gave him more of a unique flair that no other evil mastermind antagonist has. Valkyrie, on the other hand, is a complete sadistic bitch that has minimal character development and is OP as fuck. 


What am I supposed to feel after watching the whole of Gokukoku no Brynhildr? Satisfied? Overwhelmed? Sucks to say this but rather, I feel disappointed. There's a limited amount of character development, and some of the characters serve such a narrow purpose they shouldn't even exist i.e. Kotoro. The storyline in it's initial phase was awesome, but then it deteriorated into a fanservice-stained sci-fi, which is not a good blend AT ALL.    I honestly don’t get what the point of putting fan service in non-hentai animes – it’s a stupid way of attracting perverted attention. Anyways, I have yet to see if any improvements could be made in the future of GnB, but for now I am completely scrapping it, to avoid any serious injuries I could be going through. I could ramble on forever about how GnB to me was a complete let down but you know what? It wasn't all that bad and at the very least it was ENJOYABLE to some extent.

I have to say that this is my first time writing a review. So it could be pretty shitty, however I just thought that I need to write something about this anime.
First of all, I haven't seen Elven Lied or any other closely related anime, so the plot was actually kinda original to me. That said, I also have to say that the start of the anime (4-5 episodes) was decent as it introduced you into a dark story about laboratory modified people, who need help. 
Let's first talk about the first couple of episodes, as it was pretty much the only good thing Ican said about the anime. Like I said, the introduced story is interesting, as it starts pretty dark and full of mysteries. Even the introduced characters are not as bad at the beginning. You have a cute main girl, main hero who is not dumb and the other chicks are not bad aswell. So you think that this might end up a little better than you expected, but oh no... don't you dare think that!!


The show turns into shit somewhere around episode 5-6, when one of the future main characters, Kotori, is introduced. I dont really know why, but with her arrival, the bad things the characters and the anime itself had, suddenly started to show more and more. One of those things is that at the start cute chicks turned into a bunch of no-brainers and the only thing they did for the next 5 eps was show the viewers some titties. Which is not really my style of enjoying anime.

Next thing is, the creators actually seemed like they saw this dramatic decrease of IQ and decided to make the main hero the biggest genius on the planet, to even things out. As expected, that hurt the show even more, because now instead of a fine main hero you had an annoying guy who was simlpy too smart for this anime, while also being too nice to every character and made every girl in the show fall for him (while still being very annoying). I personally find it very hard to like these types of characters, as they are just too perfect = annoying for me.

The only reason I was still watching the anime, the story, also starts to fall down as the creators expanded it too much, while not explaining the unanswered questions at the beginning. And as the last bonus, you have one of the must borring villans I've ever seen in my life. 

Win-win situation? Not really if you ask me...


The art was not bad (I've seen worse), but the sound was bellow average, as I can't remember any songs from the anime, which rarely ever happens to me.


So let's sum this up. This anime starts all-right, but then turns into a shit show. The only likeable character in the show is Kana and the only good thing about the whole anime is the interesting premise of the story, which was ruined in the middle of it. Definetly not recommened.

Gokukoku no Brynhildr, another classic example of source material is more important then the anime. The anime did incredibly well up to episode 10, it honestly felt as if the creators intended to make this an 20+ episoded series, but got the bad news they had to cut episodes.
Not to mention the ending- most likely the reason why people give this anime such a low score.
Anyhow- let's get to the review.
Story ( 8/10 )
Murakami, an average boy who experienced a traumatic experience by losing his best friend Kuroneko. After almost 10 years a girl transfers in his school, a girl who remarkably looks alot likeKuroneko. Strange events start happening after she transfered in, and this is where it all starts.

To be fair- this premise might not seem interesting, but what happens after really shocked me. The story gets alot more depth with multiple mysteries that the anime presents. It builds up to the point where you are wondering 'how did this all happen'.

Sadly for whatever reason this excitement is pushed in 2 episodes, this highly anticipated moment is ruined as a result of this.


Art ( 9/10 )

To be fair, the art was fantastic. It had a dark underground tone to show that this wasn't your typical harem/romance anime. The character design was pretty good aswell, really nothing to complain about.


Sound ( 8/10 )

I honestly don't listen to openings nor endings that often, the sound that interests me the most is the sound being played during the episodes themselves. Gokukoku no Brynhildr seems to nail the battle scenes and also has perfect soundtracks to give that 'little extra'.


Character ( 9/10 )

This is honestly where the anime shines. Even while I don't think that any character is unique, I feel that every character has it's own purpose.

Keep in mind that this anime can be considered as a harem, which means that in most cases one guy ends up with multiple girls, of which only one actually is important.

In the case of gokukoku no Brynhildr every character is important up to the very end of the anime. This obviously due to the supernatural aspect of the series, but nonetheless a nice change to see every character being important for once.


Enjoyment ( 8/10 )

Granted, this anime isn't perfect, but what it did well was entertain me up to the very last second. The ending made the show worse though, not to such an extend that I am giving this show a lower score then it deserves, but I feel that if they took a bit more time and didn't rush it as much it would of been more acceptable. That aside- the story was alot more in depth and had alot more gore than I expected it to have. 


Overall ( 8/10 )

(The ending and other small aspects aside) This anime is really good. It's nothing like your average harem and has a nice dark undertone aswell.

To be fair- to get the full experience it is recommended to read the manga to continue the story. The anime ends at chapter 100, while at this point the manga is at chapter 160 or so. The manga will give more closure to those who hate the ending.

Whenever people pick up new anime to begin their seasonal run through, a good first impression of a show is always good.  Common elements like mystery and horror are often a good start, as both of those genres can differ in many different ways.  In Spring 2014, we have Gokukoku no Brynhildr, a show that for me, grasped my attention, but failed to maintain it for a long amount of time.
Story (5.95/10):  The story of this anime is essentially this.  Our main protagonist Ryota Murakami, a second year in high school, is in a bit of a conundrum.  Due toa tragic incident that occurs about 10 or so years prior to the anime's beginning, a tragedy befell on his childhood friend in whom he called Kuroneko.  Now in high school, a girl with the same name comes into his class, looking like the exact same girl that he knew from years ago but much older with motives that seem...uncertain.


Now this concept sort of grasped me into what I thought was going to be quite a well thought out show.  The possibility of a good mystery anime combined with a possibility of romance made me quite happy to see what could come out.  While the show throughout had actually some pretty nice central themes like "what is the worth of a life?" and "what is more important, your life or someone you care about?" but really apart from that, there's not really too much else.


What the show did do good on was trying to make itself seem tragic.  Which in a way, it did.  As well as presenting with a pretty decent mystery/supernatural idea and storyline that for me, sparked interest, it also made created quite a gruesome way of dying that to me looked quite terrifying and gave me a sort of shock that I really wanted from this series.  It presented us internal conflicts with its characters while, as minute as some of them might be, were decently executed in some way shape or form.


However, Brynhildr had quite a few number of flaws.  Most noticeably, its pacing and the structure of the anime.  Brynhildr is quite frankly a mess of epic proportions.  Whenever a plot point comes up that actually has a good chunk of significance to the story or when a new character or mysterious object comes into play, they don't really last very long.  To put it in short, Brynhildr tried to do too much in too little time.  The whole story lacked quite a bit of story cohesion as there was no real smooth transition from one thing to another, and the points that the show did focus more on were more or less the more boring or unnecessary parts.  I.E. Comedy and fanservice.


Another thing it had a problem with was plot focus.  The story had a lot of potential to expand and create a deeper and more meaningful plot with its ideas of secret government projects, aliens, the witches, and the motives behind the antagonists, but it just never got off the ground from where it really started.  To put it simply, the entire series focuses on finding out how to get freaking pills.  While yes the pills do have a lot of significance to the story, it was really all they focused on and it kind of felt stupid to watch a series about kids trying to find prescription drugs no matter how much emphasis they put on the importance of it.  


And finally, we have the end.  This series had the most dissatisfying end I could think of for really any series.  There was absolutely no resolution at all.  Simply put, nothing really changed.  If you watched the first episode and the last episode back to back, there will be absolutely no change to the characters overall.  (aside from additions to the cast.)  While I wouldn't discourage the series for trying to end on a happy note, (since I am a sucker for happy endings), nothing really felt resolved and it bugs me, as since there was no real character development, the whole series felt like a middle finger to the audience.  


Overall, I felt that the series focused way to much on the more unnecessary romance aspect of the show rather than the more prominent and interesting supernatural/mystery portion which in the end, was quite unexplained and broken.  While yes, this show had quite a good story base idea to it, its execution was yet to be determined.


Overview:

+  Great story idea

-   Focused too much on unnecessary plot points

-   Many points were unexplained

-   Disappointing ending.


Characters (5.96/10):  The character in this series are a mixed bag at best.  For me, I found the side characters more interesting than the actual main characters themselves.


Ryota Murakami is our main protagonist of this series.  To me, he's more or less a play by play cardboard cutout character that doesn't seem to do much beyond what he does.  Aside from having a photographic memory (which seemed way too convenient for when he began talking about it), he doesn't have any outstanding qualities about himself that make him different from any other protagonist in a supernatural harem show.


And then we have Kuroha Neko.  Our main female protagonist.  There's not really much to say about her.  Aside from having a more or less moral compass about saving the people around her rather than herself, there's not really too much to her.  Throughout he series, she does practically one thing, and that is to put herself in danger for the sake of others.  For a while, it was an interesting trait, as development like this is not what you would normally see in an anime filled to the brim with females, but as time went on, her traits became redundant and she didn't really seem to have anything else in terms of character traits.  Aside from that, what made me really angry about her character is the sort of spoiler thing in episode 3.  Because of plot convenience, (or inconvenience I should say), something that came up as an important plot point, which actually solved an important mystery in the story, became known to the audience, but not known to the characters.  (Even if it was the most obvious thing ever.)  The reason this is upsetting is because of the fact that they play this entire guessing game for practically the rest of the series, and as a viewer that knew this the whole time, it just felt quite stupid.


As for the rest of the main cast, well, we have what I call the fill-ins.  The rest of the main cast are essentially harem members that don't have much significance beyond making ecchi moments and fanservice moments (Kazumi) that I felt the show did not need.  Like seriously, it was completely unneeded and a waste of time for the show.  They didn't have a terrible amount of character exploration to them, so they felt sort of unneeded aside from the points in the story in which their "magical power" came in handy.  


As for supporting cast, this series had a lot of lost potential here.  A great deal of the supporting cast I felt, were interesting characters.  Characters from a mad scientist whom in his original character intro was quite fascinating, to other witches in the series with character traits and backstories that seemed more interesting to a good majority of the "main" witches in the series.  Another thing that the series I felt did poorly wrong were its deaths.  The deaths of the characters didn't feel meaningful in any way.  The reason being for this is because of the fact that the characters that will die usually last for about an episode or two before just dropping dead.  Aside from having a minute inverse effect on our main characters as well as popping up as ghosts when the plot demanded, there was really no point in them at all.


Overview:

+  Interesting side characters

-  Bland main characters

-  Lost of potential in characters


Art and Sound (7.35/10 and 3.33/10):  In terms of art, the series actually looked rather well done.  The characters themselves had quite nice designs and fit well with the mysterious theme of the show.  There was always this dark undertone to the colors that I felt added to what the show was trying to do with its dark and twisted themes.  The backgrounds were the same way with a very detailed looking look to it that was rather quite pleasing to the eye.  


In terms of fanservice, the show does use quite a bit of it.  Mostly, the show references breast size, a lot, and does a lot of female stripping from time to time, even to point of having a character that was totally cool with letting a guy see everything which I felt the show did not need.  The fanservice didn't completely take over the show, but I felt that quite a lot of it was unnecessary to the story overall.  (Mostly about Kazumi and her bust complex.)


Now, the sound.  The music in this show was just...jarring to listen to.  The OP's for the show were quite frankly terrible.  The first one for the show was essentially ambience music.  There were no lyrics, there were no memorable parts, it was essentially a loop of the same sound for about a minute or two that was so very boring.  To add to the flame, the show had an unnecessary second opening that for me, was the farthest thing that fitted the show for an opening.  To explain it in short, it was heavy metal music.  It did not fit with the show at all, it was quite terrible to listen to actually, and I had never skipped a piece of music in anime so fast in my life.  (I would've preferred to listen to School Day's OP than this.)  As far as the ending song goes, well, it's cute.  It's generic, but it sounds nice, and it's cute.  What made me dislike it was how little it had to do with the tone of the show.  It sounded like a track that fitted more with either a Shojo or more romance oriented anime than this one about witches, aliens, and pills.  For me, it wasn't a good fit for the show's tone overall.


Overview:

+  Very nicely detailed art

+  Good backgrounds

-   Just....terrible music.  Just terrible


Personal Enjoyment (5.89/10):  This show had a great deal of flaws.  No matter how well the idea of the show may seem, the execution is what really makes the idea of the show, show out more.  The execution for me was less than average.  The show rushed through everything too much for my taste, nothing that had plot significance was ever really explained, (like the "fertilized alien egg" that never made an appearance again after it was dropped off), and it continued to drop in new characters like bombshells, each one of them receiving less plot significance and frankly, less care from me as we went on.  (Seriously.  They drop like 4 completely new character in the last two episodes that seemed pretty damn important.)  


Overall, I did not have a pleasant experience from watching this show.  While I did have some chilling moments which made me writhe in fear a little bit from watching this series, (that's a good thing), the majority of it made me raise a bunch of questions that just were never answered.  Gokukoku no Brynhildr is a pretty poor adaptation to the original series, and once again proves that things are not always what they seem.


Overall Score: (5.40/10)

****SPOILER WARNING****
This show was a tease, in every sense of the word.  The premise, and the first episode or two, really piqued my interest- a show about a bookish guy trying to search for aliens in memory of his presumably dead childhood friend.  Then enters the childhood friend, or at least a doppleganger thereof, and we get another plot element.  Add magic, and we're set for a great-sounding show!  However, this gets thrown out the window by episode four at latest, when our male protagonist becomes a walking, talking plot contrivance, with a new non-magical skill popping up basically as theplot demands it.  This problem is compounded by piss-poor character development, opting instead for a new female character showing up practically every episode, and either joining Murakami's harem, or getting killed in 'combat' with this ever-growing harem.  


Now, I have very low tolerance for harem as a genre, but I do understand its basic appeal, if on nothing but an intellectual level- we're supposed to identify with Murakami, and enjoy having a practical army of cute girls fawning over him in the most fanservicey ways possible.  Brynhildr manages to fail even on this basic level by over-censoring the erotic elements, and detracting from the supposed budding romance between former childhood friends Murakami and Kuroha.  


After each character makes their initial appearance, they start to fade into obscurity, rather than actually develop personalities beyond the superficial.  In fact, I can even perfectly identify each character by nothing but trite anime cliches:  Kuroha the shy childhood friend, Kana the tsundere, Kazumi the sexually aggressive pettanko, Kotori the easily embarrassed, busty one.  The worst part is that they did introduce a few characters near the end that weren't total stereotypes, but they each only lasted an episode or two before they were axed from the plot.


All and all, this show is a meandering mess that even harem-lovers would dislike.  I'd give it a skip, if I were you.

When I read the summary of this anime, I was immediately interested.  The first episode had me hooked. The others? Damn, what were they a mess.
STORY-----3
If you're familiar with Elfen Lied, you will notice there are a lot of similarities between that and this anime. Don't worry it's not a rip-off, it's made by the same author and it's both about young girls locked away because they have dangerous powers. However, I hope they will learn they can not fit the manga Gokukoku no Brynhildr into 13 episodes. The plot was very slow, confusing and they just... 'threw' everything at you with no explanation.And I'm going to admit, I don't mind if a dark/depressing show has some fanservice every now and then. As long as it doesn't ruin the atmosphere, it's alright. But here? They just randomly threw in big boobs and sex jokes at the most inappropriate moments. They serve no purpose at all and were a waste of time they could spend on the actual plot. And also, don't watch this anime if you expect brave heroines. The male lead always saves the day, and the girls barely every use their power. As I said before, if you didn't read the manga this anime is confusing as hell. They randomly threw in stuff without explanation. In the last episodes, a new organization shows up, but without explaining why or what their purpose is. A lot of other things also remain completely unexplained. And the end... what kind of mess was that?


ART-----6

Fair enough. Nothing special, cute girls but everything lacks detail. Also, the eyes in this anime are super creepy. They all look like robots to be honest. The colors are dark, and nothing really bright which fits the anime.


SOUND-----7

The first opening was great, and fitted the anime. The 2nd opening? AMAZING! I only mean the song itself. It was way too brutal for this anime, especially because this has a lot of fanservice. Voice actors are simple and nothing special.


CHARACTER-----5

I must admit, I like the goal of our male lead. His childhood friend died and he wanted to honor her by proving aliens exist. He is somehow very good in remembering stuff, but never really explained why. (It doesn't need much explanation though) He -afcourse- always saves the day and all girls like him. This anime is not really a harem though, because he is in love with Kuroha and she with him, and only some sex-obsessed girl who somehow dies and comes back to life in the end without explanation is also in love with him. Honestly, I could care less for the other characters. Some of them were really cool, but they served no role in the plot expect for fanservice or being an asshole to Murakami. It did like how some of their deaths were unexpected, and quite sad. Like I said, only some of them were cool, others were these typical cliche characters (Shy girl with big tits, etc...) The villains in this show though...ugh. Never explained why they are evil, make dumb decisions and wait for every character to give their speech instead of killing them.


ENJOYMENT------5

If you're looking for a dark show, despite some of the moments, you are wrong here. Way too much fanservice, plotholes and boring moments. While some of the characters are interesting, most of them are pretty poorly written and serve no role. Despite some of the deaths, a lot of things were  predictable and each episode your questions just pile up. The end simply sucks. If you're watching this because of Elfen Lied, don't. While this has gory moments, they're very limited and ruined by fanservice. No really epic battles neither, as you couldn't see them most of the time.


OVERALL----.....6

This show is fair, nearly good, but not quite. More details down below:


-Story

The story revolves around these characters who escaped from a lab, and the problems they face because of this. This sometimes means fighting much stronger "witches," as they're called, or just finding a specific type of sustenance the witches need to survive. It's dark and brutal, so I guess the story's interesting enough. It's not dull, at least.


-Art

It looks pretty standard in comparison to contemporary works. Nothing really stands out, although overall it seems to have a more realistic art style in terms of background and coloration.


-Sound

It's all pretty standard. Nothing really stands out as amazing as far as audio goes. The opening(s) aren't really catching, as one is completely instrumental (which is interesting) and the other is extremely hard-metal (which is also interesting... in a way) The ending's catchy though.


-Character

The characters seem somewhat forced, as they act ridiculously abnormal to fit their "role" during comedy scenes. Other times, the characters act over-dramatic during the emotional scenes, which makes me laugh really hard in a scene where I should be close to tears. Murakami is stereotypical good guy main character center-of-harem person. Kuroneko is childhood friend person that's sorta just there until the final episode. Kotori is stereotypical nice polite girl. Kana is just... dumb. I don't like her. And Kazumi is overly sexual. I guess Kazumi's sexual-ness is supposed to be funny, but it's just awkward and "wtf?" most of the time, since her sexual remarks just come out of nowhere.


-Enjoyment

Despite that, I found myself enjoying the anime quite a lot. The dark side of the anime is immersive, and the action scenes are pretty good.

To be honest when I bought this anime I had no idea what to expect. But when I saw that this was created by the same guy that created Elfen Lied I just couldn't say no!
The Plot
The story follows Ryouta Murakami. Ten years ago he had a best friend Kuroneko. Together they set out to prove that aliens exists, but a accident happened and Kuroneko died because of it. Now he has dedicated his life in trying to prove that his friend was right (he joined the astronomy club and searches for aliens) Fast forward a few years a new transfer student enters his schoolnamed Kuroha Neko and she looks very much like his childhood friend Kuroneko. She denies being Ryouta's friend. She somehow aced a difficult test to transfer in, but doesn't know her multiplication tables. She possesses inhuman strength and strange abilities. And strangest of all, she predicts death.


The story really reminded me of Elfen Lied (shocker) it's a pretty good story though not as good as Elfen Lied. It has a very lighter tone to it as well. A few bloody scenes here and there but nothing major. Note there are also a bit of mild nudity. I still enjoyed the series very much. Only problem I have with it is that it needs a season 2 or some form of a continuation.


The Sound

The first Opening fit the series very well and then for some reason they changed it near the end. Although I have no problem with the second opening it didn't really fit in with this series. The sound track to wasn't really anything amazing nothing really stood out to me. That's just my opinion though


The Animation

The animation was good. I wouldn't say it was as great as it could've been but it wasn't really terrible either I'd say average at best. But it did do some of the scenes justice.


Enjoyment

I really enjoyed this anime. The story was good the characters were very likeable. Again it reminded me a lot of Elfen Lied there was even a little easter egg from Elfen Lied. Basically if you enjoyed Elfen Lied you most probably will enjoy this as well.

When I first encountered Gokukoku I thought it might be a new chance for me to watch a gory-psychological anime like Elfen lied was. First episode seemed good enough and the plot suggested me it was gonna be a hell of a show.

Before starting, I should admit that I just made a MAL account in order to defend this anime. So without further ado, here is my review.
__________________________
I think one of the main reasons that this show has received such low scores is that people, especially the manga fans, expected too much. They foresaw an exciting anime that followed the manga exactly, had great character development, a steady pace, and great action. However, with such a mindset, Gokukoku no Brynhildr was already doomed to fail. In order to even rate an anime, one must keep in mind that the people who make the anime and the mangakawho made the manga have two completely different perspectives. These perspectives might coincide, but in the case of Gokukoku no Brynhildr, they did not. Therefore, please rate an anime based on what it is. Understand that there were episode limits. Understand that some scenes had to be cut. Understand that the anime production company did what it thought was best in mind, even if it didn't come out as planned.


But enough of that, let's admit it. The anime wasn't perfect, nor was it close. It had it faults. A major problem beingpacing. As the anime neared its end, the producers just tried to finish the story, a whole lot of it, in a small amount of space. A 13 episode adaptation was definitely wrong in the first place. Not only did it leave viewers with wanting more, it also diluted the plot and action entirely. Only the absolute key points were shown, which weren't enough all together. For those of you who have finished, the final clash was reduced to seconds, was it not? And the conclusion? Let's not speak of how quick that was. And there were so many things left unanswered that I, personally, wanted answers to. Yes, it wasn't great. Yes, it could have been much more. But that's all there is to it. Let's move on to the positives.


One thing that Gokukoku no Brynhildr did perfectly was keep up the suspense. From the first episode, I was drawn in to the entire story. Witches? Special Powers? Aliens Childhood connections? Pills? "Hanesuto"? All this led me into the next episode. It truly was an enjoyable experience being thrilled like that. The first 6 or 7 episodes were definitely the highlight of the series. Not only were they exciting, but they were touching and heartbreaking at times too. It's rare for an anime to evoke so many emotions. Not to mention, some chuckles here and there.


Speaking of which, let's get on to the probably the most "detested" part of this anime: the fanservice. For those who hate it, I will warn you that there is plenty of it in there. The main initiator being Kazumi. She is the one who is always after Murakami. They had some pretty interesting encounters too. But, Kazumi, in my opinion, gets too much hate. Yes, she made the show a bit more lighthearted. Is that bad? I found it nice to have a comic relief here and there. While I will admit that it did get pretty annoying at times, overall it wasn't bad. In fact, I think the changes from fanservice to the serious plotline  really helped emphasize the emotions of the characters. And what about Kotori? Yes, she is the generic shy girl who has been blessed very graciously. But I find that to be the highlights of Gokukoku no  Brynhildr. It has incorporated so many character types that the show doesn't get boring. While the development might be nonexistant, the variety of character types slightly makes up for it.


Let's move on to the art and sound. Not much to say here, actually. The art was simple but it really suited the sort of grim, serious tone of the anime. The sound was really good in my opinion. While the second OP was really, really bad, the first OP and the ED were amazing in my opinion. They both really highlighted the show's two parts: the sci-fi mystery and the romantic drama. The OST, in general, was great (with the exclusion of the second OP because it did not suit the anime at all).


So, lastly, I would like to say that everyone should give it a try. I personally found it to be a highly enjoyable show despite its big downfalls in certain areas. For those who are looking at Gokukoku no Brynhildr's MAL page and are staring at the low score and some of the negative remarks, please don't get too much into them. I was a victim of it once and because of it, I had decided not to watch many anime that were actually very enjoyable and interesting. I am glad that I did not do so for Gokukoku no Brynhildr.

First and foremost you should know the following: this is one of those adaptations that moves along at an unhurried pace and then tries to wrap up everything in the last episode. Obviously since there are only thirteen episodes this attempt is an utter failure, with the only solace perhaps being that there is a manga version to read if you want more, and I think you will, if only out of frustration.
The CONCEPT was interesting in my opinion, especially because I didn't fully grasp it right away, and it didn't try to force a bunch of flimsy science down my throat. This series dealsmore in the emotions of the characters, and there are quite a few bloody (albeit well censored) battles to pass the time between plot developments.


The ART is solid, but I must reiterate that this is HEAVILY CENSORED. The SOUND is pretty... bad. Sometimes a show can make a simple conversation or activity seem creepy and foreboding with the right score playing in the background. This show often does the opposite.


The CHARACTERS are okay, but they also usually come with a tiring amount of cliches and (again, with only 13 episodes) there is little in the way of character development.


Your ENJOYMENT of this depends entirely on how demanding you are of the plot. This show tends to give you a lot of juicy concepts and usually it fails to capitalize on them. One thing this show does fairly well is to keep the possibility of pain and death very real from episode to episode, and from moment to moment. If you enjoy that and a harem structure with a lightweight plot and some unconventional battles and that's most of the enjoyment factor.


OVERALL this show could've turned out very, very differently. You may notice that the average opinion on this show changed drastically after the last episode, with good reason. I disagree with the criticism that this show had no real plot and too many outlandish twists, if only because a lot (and I mean a LOT) of other, very popular shows can't really claim to be any different. I only think that this show could've pulled off an epic second season, with many a glorious battle, more witches, and a whole lot more plot development, leading to a much more consumer-friendly resolution. Seeing as this show didn't do that, it is unfortunate, but very true, that this show is a teaser at best and a bunch of whiny bloody girls at worst. 


Review in a sentence: This show is worth watching if you want some gory depressing scenes with a plot that fizzles out at the worst possible moment. 


Thanks for reading.

I overall liked this anime, cause it has an interesting concept to it. A lot of people talk down to how this story has a similar feel to Elfen Lied (which is probably cause they share the same writer for the manga) but I didn't mind it- although that's probably because I haven't seen Elfen Lied yet. 
The beginning and end sequences were nice to watch. I quite liked it. The animation style was interesting and I didn't mind looking at it as much.
The story of Ryouta Murakami was interesting. I liked his determination to find out if Kuroha was actually the person he waslooking for. However his character annoyed me to no end, especially his naivety and lack of ability to do much. He's, although smart, a little bit 1 dimensional at times.\n
Whilst the characters were quite diverse in personalities and what traits they have, I felt there was a lack in male character variety, especially how all but a few male characters were actually seen as ''good'' characters as opposed to ''dark'' characters. I could be wrong though.\n
I felt like some details with certain plot devices were quite inconsistent, such as how Murakami forgot something, even though when another character (i'm not going to say who cause spoilers and that) attempted to erase his memory he was still able to remember everything.\n
I felt like the characters seemed a bit lacking in development. They remained pretty much the same people throughout. Although at times Kuroha seemed to improve in things and develop slightly, and Ryouta seemed to make better decisions and seemed ever so slightly stronger in character (to be fair he cried in pretty much every episode), Kazumi didn't seem to develop at all, neither did Kana (but she's unable to move, I'll give her that one- though her character is interesting). Kotori did show some development, however which I liked.\n
I thought that Valkryia needed more in her character. Maybe an extra episode or something. I'm unsure if she got that in the manga, cause I never read it, but it'd be nice to know more about her. We didn't get that as much.\n
The ending seemed a bit rushed. You don't learn much about what happened between the end fight and the end scene. I like how they thought about Kotori though.\n
Overall I did like, but it isn't in my list of favourite anime to say the least.

Well, it's finally over. 
A part of me wants to tell people to give this a chance. Make you're own decision about it. The other part of me just wants to tell you not to waste your time.
Story: 6  Art: 6 Sound: 6
As story line goes, it had so much potential. In the beginning I was genuinely excited to explore the characters, and learn more about the world. But the story line, quite literally, drops off. It's fairly easy to get lost, and too many things, IMPORTANT things, had been rushed.  As art goes, it was alright. It fit well with the show,but other than that it has nothing special too it. At point's it was painful to watch because characters emotions wouldn't match up with their facial expressions. As far as sound goes, the series has two different openings. The first you hear is actually pretty great, it gives you the science fiction feel the show was going for. But the second opening is a joke. I understand what they were trying to do, but as a fan of that kind of music, even I wanted nothing to do with it. As for the music in the show itself, I felt like it was always spot on, and worked really really well. 


Character:2 Enjoyment: 3


The characters were rushed, and not properly developed. Murakami, from the beginning was rather obnoxious and it only grows worse and worse through out the show. As the main character, you want to cheer him on, but he is such a sucker that you can't. The leading ladies I had more hope for, and they still fell flat. New characters enter too quickly and immediately become attached, and you really aren't given time to like any of them, considering the fact that you learn so little about them. My enjoyment level of this anime can be compared to that of watching a car crash. It's horrible, but you can't look away. I kept thinking it was going to get better, and eventually towards the end the story picks back up and you begin to think that it wasn't half bad. But still in the end, it falls short of the line.


Overall: 6


 I wouldn't watch it again, and when friend's have asked if I would recommend it I say no. The story is too rushed, you are left with to many unanswered questions, and with an unsatisfying ending. I am giving it a six because it does have it's glimmering moments. In the beginning and in the last couple of episodes, almost to the very end. You really feel like the story is going somewhere, and that you may get the opportunity to learn more. Even with characters being as undeveloped as they were, the story could have won. But they rushed it, and it makes the whole show itself bland and disappointing.

Gokukoku no Br... umm...
GnB, is an adaptation of a manga series with the same name. The premise sounds generic, but the execution is below that.
It's a mix of Dark drama and Harem. And Sci-Fi. And Fantasy. Also don't forget the Comedy.
To be honest, it's a mess
Story - 6/10
The story revolves around Murakami Ryouta. When he was a kid, he befriended a girl he call Kuroneko. She said that she had met aliens. But before she can prove that, she got involved in an accident and died.
Presumably...
Years later, he met a girl that looks exactly like her, but her name is Kuroha Neko. After a fewmisunderstandings, he helps her and her friends who are being chased by an evil organization that has something to do with aliens and artificial magic.


If that doesn't sound generic, then you probably have some unique taste.


Firstly, this anime has bad pacing. Particularly near the end. So many things are happening after another I completely lost track of what's going on.


Secondly, bad plot. Mostly the plot points. Generic is one thing, but this plot just throws sense out of the window. One moment they're talking about something that's supposedly important, the next minute everybody forgets it.


So overall, sucky plot.


Art - 6/10


The graphic isn't special. It has it flaws, but mostly good.


Sound - 7/10


Now this I can actually like. Especially the OP, it doesn't have any lyrics, but it captures that gritty feeling just right.


Character - 5/10


They're basic character archetypes. what more can I say?


Murakami wants to protect the girls. Neko wants to protect everyone. Kana has a sharp tounge. Kazumi tries to be perverted. And Kotori is the gentle soul.


Overall - 6/10


This anime is really lackluster. It tries to do too much on such a short time. 


Oh, and the ending contains no sense at all. It left many, MANY unanswered questions.


Like, "What the hell is this?!" "What the hell is that?!" "Who the hell is she?!" "What the hell just happened?!" "Why the hell did that happen?!"


This anime's ending is basically saying "READ THE MANGAS, FOOLS!!"


If you like the manga though, you might enjoy watching this, because you'll know what the hell is going on. Unlike the rest of us.
