Brynhilder In The Darkness
Art: The art style was pretty generic when it came to character design. I did enjoy the colors and the shading that made the characters at least a little unique. I found that each character style however was pretty stereotypical. I mean you had your shy, quiet, dark haired girl, a Lolita girl with some kind of affliction, the ditzy one with big breasts, and a main guy who can’t seem to get anything to work quite right, but more on that later. I did like that there was good amount of background images and the art of space were truly gorgeousto look at. While there was a bit of nudity and fan service, the version on Crunchyroll blocks it out mostly, but not in the white beam of death, more like an extra steamy bath.


Music: So the first thing you hear is the intro song and while the first one is an awesome dubstep jam, the second opener is a death metal song. I have to say I have never experience that in an anime and it was really awesome to see the liberty that they chose to have with this show.  As for the other sounds and music i felt that it went mostly unnoticed, and this could be because it blended so well with the story. I did notice a few times where the story would take a turn and the music would change drastically to accommodate that. For this I really found that the music made the show easy to listen to and the sound of certain things happening (I won’t spoil it) made me feel like i was really present with the characters.


Story: This show picks up after a tragic accident from the childhood of Ryouta Murakami, where his best friend fell to her death. 10 years later he is still searching the stars for alien life in her honor. Then, one day, a girl who looks exactly like his late best friend transfers into his class. Neko continually denies not being the friend that had passed away, but Murakami wants to be sure. Then, when she uses special magic powers to save his life from a massive bolder, it comes out that she is a Witch, or at least a person who has been given powers through dangerous experiments. Throughout the show Murakami picks up more than just Neko, and soon a whole harem of “witches” who have escaped the experiments have joined him as he vows to protect them. There is a lot of sadness, and quite a bit of romance between the girls and Murakami, but we always seem to root for one.


Personal Reflection: I put this show on my list almost a year ago, mostly because I had heard that there was a lot of fan service. But as I began to watch anime more critically I found that this kind of entertainment, while enjoyable to watch, is not what makes a show good or bad. While the fan service was not really a major part of it at all, I found that the constant back and forth that Murakami and Neko have of weather or not she is or she isn’t his deceased best friend got to be drawn out and tiring. I kept having to put this show on hold for various reasons, one of them being I had other shows to watch that did a better job of holding my interest. While this is by no means a bad show, I found that the story line was somewhat predictable and it could have used more dramatic twists and turns. I mean by the last episode I could have guessed each event individually and would have been 95% right. If you enjoy shows that are both generic and enjoyable, Brynhilder in the Darkness is for you!


Overall Rating: 7/10

Note: This review contains some mild spoilers, but shouldn't be more detailed than what you would find in an MAL synopsis. 
Watching Gokukoku no Brynhildr is like riding a train, when you know there is a train wreck coming up, but you stay on board anyway because the staff keeps serving you such delicious snacks. If you like anime that are full of the audio/visual equivalent of delicious snacks and don’t get too preoccupied with the nuances of its overall execution, you might really like this anime. If you are very particular, and only like thoroughly fleshed-out characters, realistic relationships, and calculated story arcs, thenit might be safe to pass this one by.


And if you can’t handle a bit of gore, just turn around now and walk away.


Then again, this anime is likely more enjoyable than many of the others in its genre. The series itself falls into a hybrid harem/ecchi/thriller/sci-fi category. There is a single male protagonist who is introduced in various quirky ways to various quirky females, who each have various quirky hairstyles, clothing choices, and levels of physical endowment.  


Oh, and they’re all being targeted by some sinister, evil organization. 


Oh, and they’re all in constant danger of suffering horrific, mind-numbingly gruesome deaths.


Oh, and they're all demonstrating strange, inexplicable superpowers. 


Oh, and one of them may-or-may-not be the reincarnation of the protagonist’s childhood friend, who is supposed to be very, very dead. 


But other than that they are perfectly normal teenagers living perfectly normal (albeit ecchi-infused) teenage lives in an observatory at the top of manicured, lonely, grass-covered hill. Of course, the young women quickly become romantically interested in the (mostly) pure-hearted protagonist. And while I won’t go into too many details on the story… suffice to say that when the protagonist meets them, the girls are all alive, and the story is about making sure they get to stay that way. 


The art in the series is well done, if sometimes unimaginative. It is clean and modern and approachable, an excellent choice for a bargain-bin harem anime. Don’t expect anything too ornate, and don’t expect anything too minimalistic. It strikes a good balance, and uses some great backgrounds, which I appreciate. 


The OP for this anime is actually very impressive, and was one of my favorites during the season that it aired. Beyond that, the pacing of the dialogue is occasionally off in my opinion, and some of the music is a bit cheesy, but overall the sound is fine for an anime of this caliber. 


To summarize my opinion of the show, you should know that I watched the whole thing, and enjoyed the majority of it. Ecchi anime are often made to be fluffy, stimulating, and easy to consume. Gokukoku no Brynhildr is all of those things, with an added air of mysterious tension. Though I can’t rate it highly as a whole, that doesn’t mean it wasn’t worth watching. It’s a good time-waster, a good anime to fall back on when there’s nothing catching your interest. Through all its faults, the authors definitely got a few things in the show right, and those things can make the experience worth it for their viewers. Overall, this anime is above average for harem anime of its kind; and if you wind up watching, I sincerely hope you enjoy it.

This is my first review, but it won't be my last. 
Okay so first off, this anime is straight up average. Yes it has that plot twist, but it wasn't amazing or spectacular to begin with. Although it did have some good character charisma, there wasn't any major feelings or aspect that caught my eyes. 
Story - 6/10 Linear storyline. Not much choices expect to do certain things or anything mind blowing. You have the Villian, the Hero, and the Victims. Typical Harem-action anime. Plus the story isn't too interesting. The only thing that was interesting is the ending. Which was disappointing. The ending isshort and I've felt like they missed stuff.


Art - 6/10 Good vivid colors. Not incredible like No Game No Life or Kawai Complex. Nice style for a 2014 anime series. 


Sound - 5/10 Did not really adapted the mood of anime sometimes. The opening was alright. The ending songs were okay.


Character - 5/10 I felt like they rushed it. You didn't really get all the character and why they did some stuff. I felt barely any remorse for the main protagonist and for the girl. Dang. Just wow. I wish they would extend the background story for all of them.


Enjoyment - 7/10 I really did like the suspense, but what the messed up was the phase when a character should make an appearance. Like come on, we knew she was coming from the beginning!


Overall - 6/10 Average anime. Wasn't great or bad. It's a good anime to just watch how the story turns out. Not to be emotional or feel a connection between two characters. Also the story doesn't make sense after the ending. It's just a cliffhanger and a lot of foreshadowing.

~NOTE~
- I have not read the manga to compare to the anime.
- May contain spoilers.
If I were to describe Gokukoku no Brynhildr in one word, it would be "Potential." This anime has so many bad reviews, but I think it's mainly from people who are comparing to the manga. Regardless, after seeing this anime get compared to Elfen Lied, I gave it a try since I was a fan of that anime.
-Story:   
~Pros:  When I started watching, I was just expecting exactly what the detail description says. I never would of guessed this anime would a harem. This anime is a combinationof sci-fi/ harem. As a harem anime fan, this was refreshing to watch because it is different from the normal ones you often see. (until it never picked up again.) Another thing that hit me by surprised was this story about these girls that have different powers, "witches", that escape from laboratories. As far as the story goes, I think it's good. It may not be original but it's different.

~Cons: The biggest problem with the story is, there are so many unanswered questions.  One: how did these girls end up in the labs. Two: how exactly did they get their powers. Three: why are only girls experimented. Four: how long were each girl there. 


-Art:  

~Pros:  The animation I would say it's decent. ONLY, because I expected more from an anime that aired in 2014. One thing I really liked about this anime was the first opening. That opening, I honestly don't know how to describe it, but unique and it really pulls you in. As the anime progresses, there are scenes where the girls are covered in blood. Honestly, after finishing this anime that's all I remember about the animation.

~Cons:   The fight scenes wasn't as appealing as I hoped. I didn't really care who would win.


-Sound: 

~Pros:  For the sound, the only thing that stood out to me is the first opening song, and parts of the ending song. I really thought they fit the mood of the visuals. The first opening is another example of different since it had no vocals compare to other anime.

~Cons:  Murakami's Crying.


-Character: This part of the anime is where I had so much problems with. ~Pros:    The only thing I liked was the different personalities of each character. I like how Murakami is such a nice guy. Like seriously, the man died twice, goes out of his way to jack pills for girls, almost died pulling girls up when they fall down a hill. I especially like Kazumi's pervertedness and Kotori's airheaded personalities.  

~Cons:   My Biggest problem was character development.  I somewhat remember how Murakami was tutoring this girl. What was the whole point of that, because she only showed up in two episodes and was gone. The character development was so poor done, I honestly barely even cared about the deaths. They never told us if the girls had any family, or even how their childhood are. We only know about Murakami and Neko's childhood but barely. I was sad only at Kazumi and Kotori's death because I liked them, but girls like Nanami or Hatsuna didn't really care. It felt like they added characters, and didn't know what to do with them so they killed them off. My personal problem: the romance never picked up! what kind of harem is this.


-Enjoyment: Aside from the problems, with a open mind I really did enjoy this anime. When Kazumi is perverted around Murakami, those scenes were really enjoyable. I especially like when a new witch appears, I always wonder what their power is. Scenes where Neko gets jealous and explodes things that was also enjoyable. Also found the things Murakami did for the girls was enjoyable. (things in the character section) Biggest enjoyment to me was when Murakami kicked Chisato in the face. I was waiting for someone to teach him a lesson.


Overall: Even though, there are many problems; we need to understand they only had 13 episodes so they have to rush the story.  I still say this anime had a lot of potential.  If you can easily ignore these problems, go ahead and give this anime a chance.


~ Pros:

- unique 1st opening.

-sci-fi/harem

-"witches" with different powers.

- likeable characters


~Cons:

-rushed anime

-THE ENDING.

Brynhildr was a very interesting anime - something definitely original with great characters and a great plot, but what really disappointed me was the lack of information. Brynhildr has events that take place within the anime with no reason, and they seem illogical even with the logic in the anime. Now don't assume that i hate Sci-Fi shows because i don't, but they at least stay within their boundaries and the "super natural" that occurs actually has an explanation. It started out great and i was loving every moment of it, though the comedy was provocative it was hilarious, and it had awesome characters. Butthey started destroying the plot in the end with situations that didn't make sense, and they then answered every question involving the plot with a completely absurd and ludicrous notion that was completely obtuse compared to the entire show and started trampling on all our basics beliefs, and started adding new things that were barely mentioned before and were almost out of thin air. Personally i believe that everything went downhill after episode 11. But that's just my opinion...

Brynhildr in the Darkness (holy hell is that name hard to type properly) is an anime that plays itself off as a dark, horror themed show... though it doesn't quite hit the mark.
Like Elfen Lied, Brynhildr is a dramatic gore fest and both shows are written by the same author, going as far as sharing the same general circumstances - girl(s) with superpowers escape bad research facility, the first girl that the MC meets is related to some accident from his past, yada yada yada have to secure a safe haven for the girls yada yada yada you get the idea.
So, let's begin this review.
1.Story


Brynhildr's story is almost similar to Elfen Lied, as I have mentioned in the text above and I must say that it started off strong with a fairly interesting premise to keep me watching.


While I find the wrapped idea of magic and witches very interesting, it is very hard for me to ignore the less than stellar decisions the characters make to advance the plot, putting aside the ridiculous amount of deus ex machinas as the story goes along (Kotori being the biggest culprit).


2) Characters


The fact Murakami devolves from "fairly okay guy that doesn't come off as an edgy self-insert protagonist" to "nice guy that is willing to risk his life for every girl he sees" is just mind boggling. 


He didn't grow as a character, he didn't grow a justifiable motivation for his actions at all and that makes it hard to understand why he bothers (excluding the shounen-esque "I want to save my friends!" reasoning because no, that's not a realistic reason).


As for the members of his harem (come on, you know it), they are rated from "okay" to "why the hell does she exist at all" in ascending order, starting from Kuroha and ending with Kotori. I get it, you want a shy big tits character that stumbles a lot, but honestly that is way too comical to be useful in any show that's trying to take itself seriously. So for the girls, they just sorta exist to be helpless without Murakami swooping in to help come up with some coherent plan.


There are also some gripes with the backgrounds of some of the major characters, like why Murakami lives alone and all the other convenient plot devices, but we'll leave it at that.


3) Art


I'm not well-versed with aesthetics and the particular styles of studios, but I can say that Brynhildr sports a rather generic color palette as well as decently done animations that look rather dated.


4) Sound


Now the sound department has quite a few shortcomings, what with the sudden decision to replace the honestly well-done first OP with a metal song by Fear, and Loathing in Las Vegas.


As for the voice acting, I say that the actors did their job quite well. Kazumi's VA however, has this strange lisp that just irks me to no end. Maybe it's just me, I don't know.


5) Enjoyment


With the rushed ending, the hastily introduced plot elements later on in the story as well as the rather botched attempt at recycling Elfen Lied's plot, this anime served to be a good time killer and honestly a good one at that, I have to admit.


Overall


It has its numerous flaws and it did fail to live up to the hype, but I think this is a solid mediocre anime to watch when you have nothing else to do with your time. If you don't look too hard, you'll find yourself having a pretty decent time with it.


But who am I to tell you what to watch? Take this review seriously or with a pinch of salt, I don't really care. Cheers.

I'm an avid reader of the Gokukoku no Brynhildr manga. It had me hooked, and I couldn't stop reading once I started. I was so excited to hear that an anime adaptation of the manga would be coming out. However, my excitement for the anime led to an even stronger disappointment when I watched the anime. 
The similarities between Brynhildr and Elfen Lied aside, here is my 10 cents on the  anime. The first few episodes aren't bad. They're semi-interesting, and they keep you wanting to come back for more. They also stay pretty close to the original story in the manga and arepaced pretty well. Come episode 4, the pacing suddenly speeds up. From there on out, the story starts to unfold in each episode at a much faster rate than the manga. This normally wouldn't matter so much, but I started losing the urgency that should be conveyed by the situation that Murakami and the magicians are in. What felt like several days or weeks in the manga ended up feeling like one or two days in the anime. Murakami and the magicians are in the same situation with a different character everyday? and one episode is just dedicated to the encounter with that witch? C'mon, let the main characters, and me, pee their pants a little wondering what will happen next.\n\n
 That being said, I still didn't have too much to complain about it until the last 2 or 3 episodes. The last few episodes are just atrocious. It's like they crammed 50 or so chapters and most of the important events in the manga into 2 episodes, most of it occurring in the finale. I won't sugarcoat it; the finale was unbearable. I almost didn't want to finish it because it was so bad, and I often found myself checking how many more minutes were left of this atrocity. The anime gets rid of every important encounter and removes all the suspense, action, and emotion that is evoked in the manga. I'm just really disappointed that a manga I really enjoyed was turned into a giant turd when animated.

When he loses his beloved childhood friend Kuroneko, protaogonist finds himself completely alone, until one day when he meets Kuroha Neko, A girl who looks identical to Kuroneko... What are the odds!? He then sets out on a journey to prove that she is indeed his childhood friend so he can set things right between them.
Gokukoku no brynhildr is an excellent example of poor adaptations. That is to say, while the show had caught my attention with its flawless op and its interesting ideas, it was the most compressed anime i have ever seen. It was less than 20% of the length it should havebeen, based on the source material and I would recommend the manga over the anime, not that the manga is outstanding in any way but outside of the op if anything from this show caught your eye then you would be better off reading the manga... However if you have already read it or don't intend to get to deep into the story anyway you may want to see this because outside of the broken ending and questionable length it was quite enjoyable for the time it had. Be warned there is lots of fan service.

[Adapted From Original Blog Post]
[Mini Review]
Brynhildr is not just bad in the superficial sense, with its bland characters, unfocused pacing and general stupidity, it also lacks a certain understanding about what makes story-telling actually work. Missteps are evident in every aspect of its execution, turning supposedly serious moments comical and comical moments wince-worthy, a trend which only collects towards the anime's eventual finale, as this train-wreck continues to pick up more carnage as it runs down the track. The plot attempts to emulate dark supernatural mystery, but comes of more as edgy dribble that fails to bring any real emotion into its story. Astute viewerswill notice parallels to Elfen Lied and rightly so; both stories conceived by the same author. But while Elfen was poor in every aspect, Brynhildr takes it one step further; seemingly rejecting elements that could have improved the experience in favor of the same, tired cliches that the genre has adopted into its culture over the decades. For something that tries to be dark and mysterious and exciting, Brynhildr is dull; too obvious with mystery, too stupid for darkness, and any excitement you may have had for the plot burns out quickly in congruence with those other two details. When you pair that with the unbelievable amount of contrivance and contradiction of the story, even enjoyment on the most basic level eventually is replaced with the frustration of watching an anime so incompetent that it can't even seem to grasp how uninteresting and poorly done it really is.


Nothing is redeemed as you look away from Brynhildr's flawed core and examine the aspects that most bad anime incorporate. The constant fan-service is tiresome, especially when the anime decides its a supernatural mystery again, and patience is really pushed when it becomes apparent just how little effort was put into crafting the setting and details. Action is the only vehicle left to enjoy Brynhildr, and the aesthetic makes it decent, as battles between the supernatural forces of the anime become the only time when any sort of engagement could possibly be reached. Also, if you're able to completely turn your brain off, you may be able to enjoy the completely unexpected twists that the anime pulls out of its ass, so prepubescent and under-cooked that they hardly feel real. It's so "out there" and "out of nowhere" that it's almost enduring. Almost. 


But when compared to the outright trash that the rest of the anime is, that has a vague air of grasping at straws, trying to find something, anything, that the anime does right. I mean, I feel as should be insulted as a fan of the supernatural genre, but I'm not. Brynhildr insults me as an aspiring writer, who is really doing his best to turn his ideas and experiences into stories that can be enjoyed, and seeing that something so tasteless, so dull, and so uninspired can not only be fully conceived but made into a full 13-episode anime... it's just disheartening. And it makes me feel ashamed. 


Final Verdict: 3/10


 P.S: Moles before names.

Let's get this out of the way: when I first watched Brynhildr, I hadn't seen Elfen Lied.  So I come in here with no context about how its similar or dissimilar and... I think that's probably a good thing, at least to have the perspective of analyzing it on its own.
The basic story involves a boy (Murakami) meeting a girl (Kuroha Neko) who happens to be both the spitting image of his dead childhood friend, and a "Witch" -- in this setting a young woman given seemingly supernatural powers through (initially) vague mad science-y means.  What it means to be a witch isessentially the hook for the whole story, because Neko and her witch friends are on the run from the lab that created them, and also need to acquire some resources in short supply if they are to survive.


And from there... it's actually really engaging.  Essentially every episode, something happens or is revealed that shifts the dynamics of the story, keeping it moving forward without burning up the motivation of the characters the way a weaker show might.  The show evolves essentially all the way to the final two episodes, and while this does have some bad consequences for the climax, which is a little rushed, the road getting there was pretty great.  I also enjoy that this is a show where the protagonists are very active -- most of what happens is the result of them choosing to fight their fate or engage with the world, rather than just the villains knocking on their door, though that does happen as well.  The antagonists may seem to suffer for it, since they're not very good at hunting down Murakami and his ever-expanding club of witches, but they do make threatening plays (or counterplays, as the case may be) and provide ample additional challenges to the simple and ruthless rules of witch life.


The art is really good looking, with smooth animation and engaging character designs... and best of all, really good action.  The battles in this show, and there are quite a few of them, are generally excellent.  They're not just magical zapping and they're not just traditional combat, they're a solid mixture of creatively employed superpowers, melee fighting, cat-and-mouse dynamism, and once or twice even gunplay.  There's both intensity to the fighting and real cunning in the strategy, letting characters employ their brains and their brawn, both dramatically highlighted on screen, in order to win.  Further, the action is kept engaging and high-stakes because none of it is wasted -- neither the heroes nor their foes typically make a move that you absolutely know the outcome of going in, and characters can get hit, get hurt, and importantly for the art really sell the dire nature of those hits and hurts (or lack of dire nature) so that each attack feels like it matters, like it could be game-ending.  This is in stark contrast to shows that rely on the Imperial Stormtrooper Marksmanship Academy or make too heavy use of one-sided slaighters:  In Brynhildr, the action has meaning, and you want to see the outcome for yourself rather than assuming it.


It's worth mentioning that the first OP might be one of my all-time favorite anime OPs -- it shows off action, expresses character, weaves in some pretty good symbolism achieved through quick and excellent visual metaphor, and the music that goes with it, though instrumental, is catchy as hell.


On the topic of the music and sound... it's all good.  I remember and like the voice acting for all the characters, they sound natural and easily express their different personalities while most of them also still have a good range.  It's not jawdropping, by any means, but it's very solid.


The characters, I think, might be the show's strongest point.  There are a lot of them, and the show takes its time to explore most of them.  We see Murakami, Neko, Kazumi, Kana, and even Kotori go through a lot, both their highs and their lows, and in several cases we really get to explore what makes them tick, both how they deal with really bitter hardship and how they enjoy themselves.  I appreciate that we get to see this cast both at their high points and in their deep lows and trying moments, and that most of the characters remain really entertaining people who you can have a good sense for through all of it.  The villains aren't quite as strong; most of the ones you see in the first half of the show don't have a ton of character to them, serving more as monsters or obstacles to overcome than intellectual opponents for the main cast, but one of the things the otherwise rather weak conclusion does well is develop at least a couple of the baddies that have been built up over the course of the show, Chisato and Valkyria, though it does come a little too late.


Mentioning the ending brings us to the show's biggest problem: that ending.  The movements of the ending aren't bad, technically, but for a show that had been so well-paced, it suddenly has to rush ahead.  Every episode had thrown a new curve into the plot up until the last few, but every curve had also had the time and attention it needed dedicated to it, letting us really feel the weight and understand the consequences of what just happened or would be happening shortly.  When the climax kicks off, however, the pace of reveals increases and they don't get the time they need to have their impact.  A lot of threats are raised and defused in rapid succession, and it would be easy to lose track of what the stakes are right now, as opposed to ten minutes ago.  And for a show that I praised, and I feel rightly, for the intelligence and creativity of its action, the final conflict is largely lacking in it.  The first few steps of the scene have some of the weight, and there's a good *character* moment between Murakami and Kuroneko in the middle of it, but the finish is... no clever plan, no dynamic exchange of blows, no creativity to the use of their superpowers, just throw one godly powerful being at another and hopes what comes out of the all-concealing bright light is victory.  So what should have been the show's strongest point, the chance to really pull out all the stops and give us a massive, grand spectacle is... actually kind of nothing.


That is sort of emblematic of my reaction to Brynhildr: it does a lot that's technically excellent, but I enjoyed it only passing-well for that.  And there were problems.  The evil witch-making lab seemed terminally stupid at times (even if, in retrospect, they were quite good about their contingency plans at least attempting to prevent... exactly what happened), and while some villainous characters got a little development we never did get an overarching "why" for the shadowy omniscient council behind that layer of villainy.  There are plot threads that don't quite have the scope they need to, and on the whole it feels like we shouldn't be finished at where the show ended.  And true, this is accurate, since the show ends well before the point in the story where the manga it adapts actually ends, so there is more story... though if my investigation into it after watching the show tells me rightly, the manga kind of fumbled its climax too, so I'm not sure how much anything would have been helped by having a longer, faithful adaptation rather than the truncated one we got.


Still, though, I'd very much recommend Brynhildr.  It stands on its own well, and does enough technically right, especially in the first, oh, nine episodes or so, that it's absolutely worth watching.  Just be aware that the payoff is not going to be as strong as the setup and you should be fine.  I think the most critical argument for the show is that it mixes dark and light very well.  Both the abjectly awful scenarios and conditions the characters have to endure, and how they can laugh and smile while living their everyday lives despite those considerations, are handled very well, and it makes the subjects be more likeable and relatable, as well as more human, that even when there are dark clouds on the horizon, they don't fail to grasp a ray of sunshine when they can.


Story: 8

Art: 9

Sound: 8

Character: 9

Enjoyment: 7

Overall: 8


Final Verdict: Brynhildr is carried forward by smart action, good characters, and an engaging plot, even if it ultimately does suffer in a few areas.  I'd very much recommend it.

First I'd like to say this review is purely my opinion and if you love this show I won't have anything against it, everyone has their preferences. Brynhildr in the Darkness or Gokukoku no Brynhildr is NOT a bad anime by any stretch of the means, it can be very enjoyable at the time. My score may come down to being nitpicky over everything but I just have to give my two cents just this once. I'll start with the good things:
The art style was very good, a lot of the character designs I thought were very good (Apart from Ryouta but I'll get tohim.. later.) the music wasn't too great but I didn't feel like I was listening to the same music over and over again, which is good especially for a 13 episode series. Once again this is my first review so it's gonna be very terrible and not very.. professional like. This unfortunately is all I have to say that was particularly good about the show.  


I don't know where to begin with the negatives but I'll try explaining the story. The story itself wasn't bad per say but it was more to do with how the story was presented. I've never heard of the manga before watching this show, but after a couple of episodes I started feeling bits were left out or not explained enough, and surely enough I found that 100 chapters have been crammed into 13 episodes.. that's just ridiculous a chunk of information has clearly been left out or rewritten entirely and it shows. I could not get invested at all into the struggles of the characters, especially because the characters held no weight.


So I'm going to say this now I hate Ryouta with a passion, everywhere I read about this show he is labled as a smart male protaganist, but all I see is a bumbling fool who is too stupid to realise that KUROHA NEKO IS KURANEKO (I hope this is not counted as a spoiler because it really shouldn't be, anyone would figure this out just from reading the summary) now I'm no Japanese expert but if you're a genius this should not have been so difficult to figure out. This is even more annoying by the fact that he has photographic memory so he remembers details and he looks exactly like her.  My favourite characters in the series were Kogorou and Chisato and they had the least screen time. The anime also tries to pointlessly through nudity about just to keep the viewer interested, I'm a person who is all for fan service but it is done sooo very poorly to the point it hurts. Lastly over the characters I will say Ryouta earned immense bonus points at the end of the extremely rushed anime.


This anime couldn't even get the action to keep me interested because every single fight scene had to involve minutes of talking and flashbacks while the protaganists friends are having enemies trying to kill them with devastating powers, NOW IS NOT THE TIME FOR A FLASHBACK YOUR FRIEND WILL DIE. There are also so many moments that could have been avoided if they acted instead of talking and staring at each other!


This anime just was Cliche! the series, I never really took notice of anime tropes until this show shoved them all in my face. The ditzy male protagonist that is not interesting but is still the plot device and hero that all the females fall in love with, anything remotely sexual is said all the characters start blushing like mad rather than saying something rational like any normal human being would. Now there is mild nudity in this anime, I'm not sure whether this was just censoring or how the anime is intended to be even on a blu-ray release or whatever. But when you have girls in bikinis and there's massive cleavage, don't bother taking off the bikini if you're gonna make a shine that covers 10x more than the bikini. It just.. it doesn't work? 


I really wish I could go over more because there is so much I have to get off my chest about this anime that jarred me, but any further information would turn out to just be spoilers. Overall this anime is not the worst albeit very frustrating, it wouldn't be something I recommend watching but at the same time you can't really argue for anyone wanting to watch it. If I had not watched as many anime as I have this would probably be a 7/10 at best but that's not the case. So it receives a 5/10 mediocre, average. Nothing new nothing groundbreaking just a heap of the same old stuff we see with any harem ever with a bit of gore.

This show reminded me alot of Akuma no Riddle for one reason: I was on board with the plot for most of the show, but then the last episode(s) end up leaving a sour taste in my mouth.
Plot: Pertaining to the speed at which the plot progresses, most of the show was a decent pace, easy to follow and enjoyable. Then, the last few episodes decided to hop onto a military fighter jet and move at mach 1. The ending is a bit of an anti-climax and made all the build-up seem pointless.
Art: The art was nice for the most part, except for all thecensorship. It's an R rated show, show the violence.


Sound: Liked the first intro, not the second. Insert songs were decent.


Characters: I did enjoy most of the characters, but there weren't really anything special about them.


Enjoyment: Enjoyed the show for the most part, but like I said, the ending leaves a bad taste in your mouth.


Overall: I honestly would have given this show an 8 if it didn't mess up the ending so badly. I do plan on reading the manga to see what the original was like and to see how the story was supposed to be.

I am not one to ever publicly announce my opinion on anime but I was seriously misled and wish to save future viewers of the same mistake.
I was under the impression that this anime was similar to elfen lied due to "gore". Couldn't be less true. This anime is a harem anime disguised by a story that includes some gore. key word = some. Nowhere to the extent of elfen lied. So, if you like shows like elfen lied, Future diary, Gantz, Attack on Titan, Deadman Wonderland for the gore factor do NOT watch this anime. Very very big disappointment. 
If you DO LIKE ashow that looks nice and has a bunch of girls fawning over one male, boob jokes, non stop references to loosing ones virginity, lots of blushing, an extremely rushed story, and occasionally someone getting cut in half or melting then go for it this is definitely for you. The great thing is it was only 13 episodes so I didn't waste too much of my life watching it.

Have you ever had a plate of fruit that was so delicious and then one unsuspecting bite you end up biting into a rotten piece and you end up forgetting the good pieces because that rotten piece left such a bad taste in your mouth? That's Gokukoku no Brynhildr in a terrible metaphor I just made up. 
  I'm writing this review immediately after watching Gokukoku no Brynhildr, and the two words I keep coming back to, to describe this show is 'rushed' and 'disappointing',  so lets go over why I keep coming back to these two words.
  Disappointing -A show that started out so promising with its opening few episodes slowly devolves into an ecchi/harem, there's nothing wrong with ecchi and harem shows by itself, but when an anime leads you to believe it's one thing, then takes a 180 halfway through to be a completely different show, it feels misleading and ruins any investment I previously  had from that point. Even after I realized that this show was not what I originally thought it would be (and was described as) I decided to keep watching because I actually enjoyed the characters and comedy, even if they both fell under tropes that I've probably seen a million times. Little did I know that any enjoyment I would have gotten from this show would slowly be ruined as the show nears its end...


  Rushed - Gokukoku no Brynhildr starts off as a pretty good show, episodes 1-3 introduce Ryouta, our "I need to protect my friends even if it means sacrficing myself" main character, Kuroha a witch with a similar mindset, and Kana who is a paralyzed witch who can look into the future and see when people are about to die, Kana helps Kuroha in her mission to help save people who are about to die, it's explained that witches rely on a pill cleverly named "death supressants" (Yes, I'm serious.) to stay alive or else they'll melt, after a series of events and a new character who is also a witch named Kazumi with the power of super hacking abilities is introduced, they manage to get more pills, and they all go to Ryouta's school and join the astronomy club so they can hide out in an observatory for the astronomy club. This is where things start to go downhill. 


  In episode 5 we are introduced to our final important character Kotori, and how is she introduced? Well she just transfers into the same school as our characters and also just so happens to join the astronomy club,(a club that literally nobody else in the entire school joined) wow what a set of uncanny coincidences! Anyway after Kotori is introduced the show quickly becomes an ecchi harem where each girl (besides Kana) falls under a certain trope, Kotori is the big boobed, dense always giggly girl, Kazumi is the insecure small boobed girl who has a secret crush on Ryouta that isn't really a secret because she literally throws herself at him multiple times in the show, Kuroha is the shy, 'girl next door' character that also has feelings for Ryouta but doesn't understand her feelings, and finally we have Ryouta who is supposedly a genius with a photographic memory but doesn't understand why Kuroha gets mad whenever Kazumi teases Ryouta with 'lewd' talk.  


  So after all the characters are set up there is a reptitive formula to this show, that trys to make it seem like the plot is moving forward when in reality very little is happening, this formula is summed up as 'Evil scientist antagonist who created all witches sends out a witch (each one gets progressively stronger as the show goes on) that gets defeated by our characters. This goes on until about episode 9, when they go into full on "rush the shit out of this show and make any enjoyable elements we had completely ruined" They end up introducing TWO more characters that are only there for plot conveniences (one to guide the character in a later episode and one to revive the character), anyway our Evil scientist character finally says "f*** it i'm done" and goes into the council (a group of people that meet with evil scientist in a strange room that are never really explained = the council) to tell them he's going to release the strongest witch named Valkyrie, the council tell him not to but he already released Valkyrie. Valkyrie and evil scientist end up confronting our characters and out of no where a completely new faction (that was only ever hinted at) shows up to try and kill all the witches, out of sure plot convenience evil scientist, Valkyrie and the witch that the evil scientist was after teleport to some cabin.  From this point on the viewer is barraged with new information that makes very little sense. 


  The last episode alone makes this anime that I could have easily given a 6, a 4, I really can't explain why this last episode is so bad without spoiling it, but Kuroha ends up beating Valkyrie and looks up, and asks Ryouta one question, and this question is the end of the show. They literally ended the show with  more questions than answers, and there were ALOT of questions before this scene with Kuroha and Ryouta. 


  The sad thing is the last few episodes really didn't need to be rushed as much as they were, there was SO MUCH filler in the earlier episodes that they could have just sprinkled in bits and pieces as the show went on, to give an example of how much filler there actually is, there was an entire episode dedicated to the girls getting a high test score so they could go to the beach! If the show wanted to be a harem comedy, that's fine, but this show couldn't decide what it wanted to be and ended up suffering miserably for it.

You've been to Walmart before right? Well, you know how they have cheaper versions of products that you've grown used to -- and how those products never particularly live up to the hype of whatever thing they're supposed to be replacing? Yeah, well Brynhildr In The Darkness is basically that, but turned into a 13 episode anime. Now, I just want to note that discounted versions of reliable products aren't always necessarily "bad," but that at some point, you just have to bite the bullet and be like, "Man, I wish I bought the brand name one instead."
Brynhildr is the latest animated series from LynnOkamoto, the original creator of the masterpiece that we have come to know as Elfen Lied. And while Elfen Lied may have explored many different themes and ideas that were, at the time, not very common to the anime community, this new series embarks on a new exploration of the same things and tries to make it look like it's discovering them all for the first time. Basically, Brynhildr In The Darkness is the Christopher Columbus of anime. Columbus showed up in America one day and was all like, "I am the first person to find this!" while all of the Native Americans who were already over there were just like, "Dude, what about us?" and then he killed them all. This is the same thing.


Brynhildr focuses mainly on the life of Ryouta Murakami, a seemingly average dude with an above average intellect. After watching his best friend from childhood plunge to her death while they were trying to walk across a huge pipe thing (Or something), Murakami dedicates his life to astronomy because...well...that's what his dead friend liked and stuff. So one day, several years in the future, a girl looking exactly like her (Kuroneko) escapes from some lab thing and is ultimately discovered by Murakami, who is then like, "Yo I thought you were dead," only to be greeted by, "Wtf are you talking about? I'm a witch lol". So obviously the correct thing to do in this situation would be to run away from this creature with ridiculously abnormal telepathic power. But, instead, Murakami helps her assimilate with the average high school kids because that's totally not dangerous at all.


As time goes by, we discover that Kuroneko and the rest of the witches must take some pill to suppress their power from leaking out and demolishing them. Obviously, though, this pill isn't sold behind counters and must be acquired directly from the lab the witches are from. Considering at this point in time our home team consists only of Murakami, Kuroneko, and the quadriplegic best-girl (Kana), more help must be recruited. You know what this group needs? A Tsundere. So they go find one (Kazumi) and apparently she is a super-hacker that helps Kuro and Murakami break into the lab and get some life-pills. All is fine and well until the dude who I guess owns the lab is like, "Shit, we should get those witches back" and starts sending better witches after them. So then some more stuff happens and Kuroneko gets cut in half. But that's cool because the witch they were fighting against has the power to rewind time and of course she ultimately winds up doing so because the main girl can't die before the halfway point of the series.


After escaping from the evil laboratory for the second time, Kuroneko and Murakami realize they're in some deep shit. More witches keep being sent out to find them, each one stronger than the next. So the rest of the series is a bunch of rinse-repeat as the astronomy club repels their murderous attackers while slowly gaining more good witches to join their club. Eventually, the main evil guy from the lab is like, "Know what? I'm just gonna unleash the super bad witch to track them all down." The super bad witch winds up being really mean and puts a serious damper on things when she [kind of] kills one of the good witches. Kuroneko gets really mad at this because she is also a good witch and then decides it's time to unleash her ultimate power and kill the evil super bad witch lady (Who is also her sister. Surprise!). Then yay, everything goes back to normal. Or does it?...


If you couldn't tell by now, Brynhildr in the darkness is basically a slightly-tweaked retelling of Elfen Lied with more girls and fanservice thrown in. In fact, almost every single thing that happens in Elfen Lied also happens in this series. Here, I'll break a few down with this cool timeline.


Elfen Lied: Lucy escapes from the isolated evil lab and is taken in by the good guy.

Brynhildr: Kuroneko and Kana escape from the isolated evil lab and are taken in by the good guy.


Elfen Lied: Evil lab dude sends out Nana and Bandou to track down Lucy.

Brynhildr: Evil lab dude sends out like five different witches to track down Kuro.


Elfen Lied: We discover that the lab is genetically modifying cute girls to create superweapons.

Brynhildr: We discover that the lab is genetically modifying AND CLONING cute girls to create superweapons.


Elfen Lied: Woah, Lucy is actually Kouta's childhood friend!

Brynhildr: Woah, Kuro is actually Ryouta's childhood friend!


Elfen Lied: Lucy prevails and Nana now has no limbs.

Brynhildr: Kana's limbs don't even work in the first place.


Elfen Lied: Evil lab man gets fed up and sends out Mariko (Who, for some reason, loves evil lab man).

Brynhildr: Evil lab man gets fed up and sends out Mako (Who, for some reason, loves evil lab man).


Elfen Lied: Mariko's powers aren't enough to kill the protagonist. Evil lab man shows soft side and dies with her on a bridge.

Brynhildr: Mako's powers aren't enough to kill the protagonist(s). Evil lab man shows soft side and dies with her on a balcony.


Okamoto couldn't even get creative with the names of the characters. Kouta/Ryouta are the protagonists. Mariko/Mako are the bad guys. Honestly, I think it might be possible that Okamoto was just trying to relive his glory days with this. After Elfen Lied came out, everyone saw him as this mastermind with a fantastic story to tell -- which, he was. Since that, though, nothing he did really took off the same way. It wasn't until he basically rewrote the story that he put into the spotlight again. And honestly, if he hadn't already created Elfen Lied, this would have been a lot better. The characters are actually extremely lovable and I was incredibly surprised by how much they grew on me. The fanservice is a little heavy in this series, but the comedy is actually the best part of the entire show. Some scenes literally showcased 10/10 humor and made the watching experience increase tenfold. I tore apart the series above, but it really wasn't THAT bad. There are still some elements that really make this a relatively enjoyable show. However, certain things like Okamato's new-found hatred toward permanently killing off his characters, I would definitely change. 


All in all, this series was enough to make me want to read the manga, so I guess it worked it the end.


In Summary:

Just watch Elfen Lied instead.

Brynhildr is an anime based on a manga written and drawn by the same guy who did the Elfen Lied manga. The Elfen Lied manga was a lot like the anime though the anime tied things up at the halfway point of the manga. This led to a huge problem because the anime ended very early without explaining anything but the manga continued and made a little more sense after the anime’s cut-off point (though went batshit and fell apart).
Enter Brynhildr, an anime that is based on a manga that is ongoing and basically has every problem Elfen Lied had and then some. It endsabruptly, it doesn’t explain things, it’s basically some freaky fetish show for people who like their girls dead. It has all the awkwardness of Elfen Lied combined with an even stupider plot that isn’t even the cheesy, enjoyable story of its’ predecessor.


Ryouta Murakami knew a girl back in the day named Kuroneko who he loved to stargaze with. Things were going great until they decided to, of all things, climb around the side of a dam. Of course being dumbass six year olds they don’t realize they’re probably going to die and thus does Ryouta slip and drag Kuroneko with him to a squishy death fifteen stories below. He lives, she dies. Moving on.


She winds up transferring into his class ten years later, joining his astronomy club, and getting him mixed up in some bullshit about witches and aliens and labs. Turns out she doesn’t remember him at all and has telekinetic abilities thanks to a plug on her neck. There are quite a few girls like this Ryouta meets and, inevitably, he starts a harem with them. If they use up too much power the plug stops working, if a certain button is pressed on it they’re unplugged and they melt into goo.


Brynhildr seems pretty tame for the most part until it begins to talk about these pills the girls have to take in order to stay alive. If you don’t take the pill, you melt. So some drama about getting pills comes up, Ryouta and his harem of witches fight against the lab that made them the way they are, and, as you would expect from the writer of the source material, a lot of girls die horribly.


What’s problematic about this show is the pacing is terrible considering how much is going on. Things are slowly revealed, with the final revelation being at the end, but we aren’t given enough revelations throughout for the plot to matter. And once the final revelations of the series crop up they’re so rapid fire and stupid you’ll most likely groan rather than drop your jaw.


What happens here is the problem of attempting to invest us in a harem of girls with no personalities. It does this through a variety of means that may work to the horny fanboys but not to people with a modicum of intelligence.


It uses nudity as a means to get us into the characters, same as Elfen Lied did. Boobs and lame personalities are the tools that are meant to invest us in the experience and sadden us at the end of the show. But it doesn’t happen.


The problem of the characters is compounded with the fact the ending is abrupt and needlessly violent. It had no drama to it. The bad guy here has been looming over things but the girl who they fight has no personality and was introduced two episodes back. There’s also a resistance movement that was introduced the episode before that (though did stand in the shadows a little). By the final confrontation we’ve been told all about aliens and killing humans and this, that, and the other to a point where, as a viewer, I didn’t give a shit. I say the cardinal sin of a first episode is boring the viewer and not pulling them in. The cardinal sin of a final episode is having no drama and not leaving you wanting more. And you’ll have that problem when you introduce so many new characters and ideas in what is essentially the home stretch.


Let’s jump back and talk about the pacing of this show though because it, to me, is the real issue. Brynhildr wants to be a harem but as a harem it sucks. Then it wants to be a depressing drama but, let’s face it, it’s not. It fails at both genres but maintains that it wants to jump between each. The beach episode is cute and all but does it belong in a show that ends with a possible apocalypse and is focusing on girls who can die at the flick of a switch? You can have comedy and general silliness in drama but it doesn’t work as a counterbalance to the sad happenings. Instead it makes the entire show a slog to watch.


This is a poorly written anime (but better than some recent shows I’ve watched *cough*) with some of the most amateur directing I’ve seen in a while (so many abrupt cuts and fades to black that you’ll scratch your head wondering what the hell just happened).So as an entire package, it’s the most underwhelming show I’ve done a full review on in a long time.


Let me give you a little insight into individual characters so you can see why I didn’t care and where I was slightly weirded out.


The main girl and love interest is Neko Kuroha, the girl from Ryouta’s past who doesn’t remember him. She’s cute and all but her personality is kind of flat. She blushes when she has to and acts like the typical partner in a lame romance so comes across as very two-dimensional.


Kotori Takatori is the same way. Huge boobs, clumsy, and shy. Woop-dee-fucking-doo.


Kazumi *Unpronounceable German Name* is a sex fiend who just wants to fuck. Personally, as cardboard as she was I thought she was fun and added some silly moments.


And we’ll end this discussion with Kana Tachibana, the immobile girl who can’t eat by herself or do much aside from type on a little device that spits out a computerized voice to speak for her. And somehow, that device manages to capture the voice of a tsundere…


Even more disturbing is how she’s sexualized. Later we find out why she’s the way she is but the occasional sexual scene with her is fucking disturbing to me. Who is getting off to the girl who needs help eating?


They all have a variety of powers such as hacking into computers or the classic “premonition of bad things happening only when convenient” ability.


All the other characters are more of the same, lame and poorly developed creatures of which I don’t really care if they die or not.


The animation is dated leading to some uninspired character design and wholly underwhelming action sequences. The first opening song was good but the visuals that go with it are too slow for the faster rhythm of the music  On top of that, the opening shows shit that doesn’t even happen in the show which is pretty dumb. The second opening is Japanese screamo and not too bad.


Brynhildr is occasionally funny and can be decent at times, but isn’t decent enough of the time for me to care. It’s pretty much the same shit as Elfen Lied and doesn’t even try to distinguish itself from its predecessor. It looks generic, it feels generic, and it is generic. You’d be a happier person without this show in your life and I’d be a happier person if I could find a freaking 2014 anime that doesn’t suck.

There are some ending spoilers in this review, but I honestly don't think it matters since to me this anime wasn't worth watching anyways. I would never wish these 13 episodes upon anyone, especially when it only ends in disappointment. 
I've never written a review before and I watched this anime quite a while ago, so this may not be the best in terms of memory or writing. I do remember, however, absolutely hating this anime.
Sure, it had its positives. I did find charm in some of the characters and this show's overall premisis, but other than that I can hardly say anything good aboutit. The openings in this series to me definitely make it seem a lot cooler and show more promise than the series actually has.


There are many moments in this series where I experienced second hand embarrasment, dreadfully so. The main character was an absolute failure in my own opinion and I could hardly stand him, let alone the other "main" female cast that was shown as well. 

Everyone shown basically had no relevance to him in the end, only his love interest, who I believe was named Kotonoha. All of the characters working together was shut down in about the final episode, where these characters were killed off one by one in a series of reaching the final stage. I fondly recall being terribly at a loss for why I had taken the time out of my life to watch this animated series in the first place, and I also wondered why it had been brought into existence. 

The whole show was just so ridiculous to me, attempting to appeal to its audience while failing miserably all the same. It's just really not worth it, and I'd even say I enjoy a series such as School Days a lot more than this.


I'm not the best writer or anything and my points are definitely not spot on, especially since it has been a while since I've seen this, but I would never ever risk rewatching this anime even to make a decent review. I would save yourself some time and not go through these episodes.


If you want to then I can't stop you, and if you actually enjoyed this then I congratulate you in being able to withstand or even find the good in something as truly mediocre as Gokukoku no Brynhildr.
